Stellaris is not perfect. The UI is still, even after a few patches, a bit clunky for someone who hasn't weaned themselves on an earlier Paradox title to get used to. The AI is not terribly bright, particularly when it comes to moving fleets. Victory is achieved exclusively through military hegemony: you either make every starfaring race your vassals, wipe them out, or claim the majority of the habitable worlds in the galaxy.   Despite its flaws, Stellaris is still a lot of fun to play, and has a lot of room to grow. Paradox have brought together some of my favorite features from other games, both from other 4X space games and Paradox's other titles. Its diplomacy system is very similar to the one in Europa Universalis. It has a first contact system that is very reminiscent of the one in Sword of the Stars, where you can never be certain if an unknown alien ship is going to be hostile or not. Stellaris also has Grand Menaces that can really shake up a stagnant late game, much like Sword of the Stars. The ability (and in fact it is necessary once your empire starts to really grow) to automate 'sectors' under the rule of leader characters also gives the game a tiny bit of a Crusader Kings 2 vibe, especially when those sectors begin to get unruly.  By far my favorite part of Stellaris, and what truly sets it apart from other entries in the genre, is how I end up talking about it. I won't tell someone about how I couldn't win a war until after I advanced my ground combat tech; I'll tell them about how my squishy fungus people were so miserable at ground-fighting that I had to develop artificial intelligence and build legions of droid soldiers to fight my wars for me. I won't tell someone that robotics technologies let you construct pops that don't have penalties on worlds that your species can barely inhabit; I'll talk about how the advent of independent robots allowed my empire to colonize and exploit worlds that were beyond our abilities before, as we seeded entire worlds with billions of AI-controlled robots to mine worlds with prohibitively harsh climates. I won't say that I lost the game because my reliance on AI techs meant that an event triggering an AI rebellion was beyond my means to put down. I'll tell people that I reached too far, grasped for too much, and ultimately built the steel boots that would be at my neck.  Stellaris is not a perfect game, but it oozes potential, and Paradox has proven in the past that given time, patches, and DLC, they can deliver on that potential. I'd understand if you didn't buy Stellaris now, but at the very least it belongs on your wishlist, because this is a game to keep an eye on.

Stellaris has a different approach to 4x space games, and some of the design choices are great and I really feel like they could change the entire scope of the genre forever, for the better, but some of the design choices fall utterly flat. This was an experiment, both for a company that has never done 4x before and for a genre that has not fully realized its own potential yet. I recommend that people play the game, but I cannot in good faith recommend that someone spends money on this game at this time (unless you are already a huge 4x space and sci-fi fan).   A quick run-down on what this game is. Its a 4x space game, with all the elements you would expect from the genre.  What it does well:  - Tons of random events, a focus on exploration, events tied into research etc.  - Good diplomacy, with AI empires reacting dynamically to you - A novel attempt to limit the amount of micromanagement. It comes at a good time in the game, and without giving control over to the AI it would bog the game down in boring base building.  - Dynamic civics that actually matter - great role-play ability - some deep and dynamic gameplay elements  What it does poorly: - Bad boring combat - Bad sound design (stuff sounds dumb I want future weapons to sound cool, not like someone jumped on a trampoline, the soundtrack is terrible and super repetitive) - Communicating some gameplay elements to the player (the game flat out never tells you things that can ruin your playthrough if you are not aware of them) - Base building is boring, flat, not dynamic.  - Terrible ship design - Lack of galaxy variety/custom galaxies  - The literally worst victory condition, ever.   As I said, Stellaris tries to do things differently. They try to focus on exploration, but lack any incentive to mid-late game exploration (but it does add tedium) and lack almost any art assets associated with exploration. They try to make research more random and uneven between empires with research cards, which flops compared to having just a standard tech tree with % to unlock. But the biggest sin this game commits, its biggest failure and what makes me not recommend the game right now, is the victory conditions. There is only one way to win, and that is to conquer the galaxy, and there are no alternate objectives. Does not matter if you forge alliances with all other spieces and bring peace, does not matter if you finally replace all your empire's filthy organic citizens with nice clean synthetic lifeforms, you must conquer, with your military, every other empire in the galaxy. This is just insane in a game that offers so many options, to then just shuttle you down a single tight and frankly the most boring path of the game in order to win.   And this is an easy fix, either remove victory conditions entirely and embrace the sandbox or just allow players to set custom victory conditions like research a specific technology, reach a certain % population of a species, eliminate slavery in the galaxy, or ALLOW ALLIED VICTORY. The rest of the problems with the game simply come down to 'finish the half-baked pieces of your game', which based off of the company's history and their stated plans for this game, they will do through DLC.  And btw, I know that someone will say 'just do your own victory conditions on your own', to which I say, 'this is a video game, it is literally the developers job, they decided to have an ending for this game and that ending sucks and has an impact'.  PS Achievements are completely broken in this game for most people, they simply never register or work. Does not matter to me, but I know some people care about that sort of thing so I thought I would do you the service.

TL;DR: get this game on a heavy discount. It's too dry.  I will say this: the game is fun enough at the start for you to think you made a great buy, and then play it for long enough to pass the return policy timing. You will spend many of these hours being impressed by some of the surface brilliance the game pushes (art work and music is great), and probably learning the various details of the game (like weapon types/enemy types/travel mechanics etc).  Afterwhich, you'll start to think that maybe this wasn't the best buy, because there is a kind of repetitive dryness to the game that I can't quite put my finger on. There isn't much in the way of complex AI, trading, diplomacy, or battle mechanics. It seems like the AI will engage in what is largely the same type of 'camp-then-mass attack' tactics as a bad TW game.  And in response you will attempt to do basically the same, building enough of what you need (which isn't diverse or complex enough to be sustainably interesting), then attempting to blitz the opposing sectors. And you will rinse and repeat that process until you have, after many dry hours, taken over enough to the galaxy to win.  The game, in the longer run, leaves much to be desired.

It is hard to not expect too much from a game by a studio that has created such wonderful time-consumers as Hoi3, EU4 and Crusader Kings 2, and it is hard to not be too unfair in the face of such disappointment. But this game just isn’t ready yet.  There are several new and original ideas, like edics (political decision) and factions (political organizations of discontent citizens), individual ethics (political preferences of each single population) and fun government types, like you would expect from paradox’ rich and fruitful strategy experience. But the fact that any cool empire management feature (edicts, allicances, planetary programs, border expansion, faction management, government decisions, leaders and governors, even certain buildings and moving population around) requires “influence”, by far the most valuable resource, effectively takes all of this out of the game, since you are always trying to save your points and do without.  Sound and graphics are from 10-15 years ago, surely not as important in a strategy game, but in this case made so lackluster and dull, it hurts the gaming experience. At least an animated landing of a colony ship should have made it into the budget. What you get is a stamp-size picture with the graphics quality of a steam achievement.   The menu is intricate and counterintuitive. You have a colony ship and want to see a list of possible planets? Not possible. You are on the star chart and want to click on your colony directly? Not possible. You are on a planet and want to switch though to the next? Not possible. You always have to click all the way up, all the way down. To put something on a building list requires all the resources immediately, which you can never afford. So no building lists either. Click, click, click. The game should come with an extra mouse, for wear and tear reasons.  The entire gaming experience feels like an Early Access. There are just so many things that remain unfinished and incomplete, it seems that the developers have first and foremost spent their creativity on one question: what else of the things you would normally expect from a 4x space game (and that was already there as early as Master of Orion 2) can we take out of the game to later sell it to the players as DLC?     Victory conditions? YES, take it out!    Tactical Battles? YES, take it out!    Diversified troops? YES, take it out!    Galactic Senate? YES, take it out!    Capturing Ships? YES, take it out!    Espionage? YES, take it out!    Forceful Diplomacy? YES, take it out!    Planet view? YES, take it out!    Cool Graphics? YES, take it out!   It’s almost funny the race designer made it in, you would think they’d have made that a DLC too.  Apparently the developers don’t care for the game or the players, only of your money. Do so too. And save it.

They can really shakeup the aforementioned slow late game. That's just not enough to really make the whole game feel worthwhile. Since the latest patch, a lot of the things that annoyed me were fixed, but there's still a lot of missing features (to be DLC I'm sure) and design choices that I question. Overall, it's certainly not a bad game. But it's not that great either, in its current state anyway. Stellaris has the potential to be another Paradox great, but it's lacking depth right now. I would wait another year, after a few DLC's have come out, then try to pick it up on sale.

Maybe in 2 years with some DLC will this be any good. It is unbelieveable how gullible people are and how companies can get away releasing such an unfinished product hidden behind a bit of graphical niceties. Such a game and its hype and broken mechanics is a pretty good reason not to buy games anynore.  Never again from this dev.

Stellaris offers what many of us have been missing in that it is real time 4x space strategy game. Finally no more “end turn” right? Freely customizable race, easy modding, and a nice arrangement of traits/characteristics allow for replay ability. Keep an eye out for mods in workshop though as they will probably be able to take the vanilla game further in its current state.  Diplomacy could use some work. Coming from an experience like CK2 where there is such a detailed level of advisors, intrigue, relationships, etc.… you will be underwhelmed by the diplomacy. Like no joke, there’s not much to it…   Planets… So I am not sure if I am for or against this rather dated style of planet/colony management. It reminds me of Master of Orion where planets have tiles which can be modified to produce a resource based off the building. It works for the game so I have no real complaints on it, just seems like an old mechanic that we have seen before. Something I’m not too fond of is the planet control system and how your kind a forced to give up control of your systems to a governor after you a mass a few colonies. I suppose if there was more interaction or even the feeling that I was handing over my territory to someone of value it wouldn’t be so bad. However, it feels quite static. Made me miss CK2 and long for those intriguing back stabbing plots to break away or declare independence from my rule. There is little you can do to control how you want your sectors run and leaders again are quite static. Not to mention limited in availability. Don’t expect to have scientist, generals, admirals, and leaders everywhere or even in all the above areas.  So combat is indeed 4x, but doesn’t really feel like it. More or less move one fleet onto an enemy fleet and they swarm around firing. No direct player control. Again, not a complaint, it works. And the UI window on battles during and after offers more details to help redesign your ships versus CK2 UI. Sadly I feel the 4x component is wasted in this though…  Overall the game is very vanilla, like not even vanilla bean, or vanilla with sprinkles….it’s just vanilla. However, mods and time will tell if Paradox adds to it and brings us the enjoyment we have seen in other titles (CK2) (I mention CK2 because I’d so die happy for a CK2 in space type game). I am enjoying it though and have already logged many hours since its release here.   I will leave you with this thought… Recall back to the early days of CK2 and how it was at first launch, or even some other titles… I’m just looking towards the future and ready to reach for my pocket book for the plethora of DLC to come. :)

After buying Stellaris and playing it for a bit I wanted to share some of my thoughts as the one true ruler of the Glorious Empire of Man. Humankind...People of Terran Ancestry...err anyway once we sort the naming out I'll get back to you.   My brethren followed while I led them on a noble quest to scan our local planets (The heck - I didn't see Pluto...WHERE DID PLUTO GO?!). From there I scanned local star systems, and settled some of the scruffier humans (They claimed they were 'Individualists' - but look...showers were invented for a reason people...) on distant worlds.   In an inspired moment I promptly declared war on some local gang of rednecks claiming to be a Fallen Empire. I think it went well, I mean it did offer our scientists a nice close up view of a death ray, which really helped our theoreticians...  Errr..yeah don't do that. Anyway this game really sucks you in, I had just bought DOOM and it's just been gathering the digital equivalent of dust once I started playing this. I like how leaders (scientists, fleet admirals, planetary governors, generals) actually age – and die (make sure you keep some influence in reserve to buy new ones).   The way the game handles tech is...different. There isn't so much as a tech tree as a choice of semi random technologies to pursue. This can be a little frustrating when a tech you didn't choose to research in the past doesn't show up again. Certainly makes you think about tech choices in a different light. As my empire grows I am beginning to see how managing a larger and larger empire takes more and more time, although I suppose this is true in most 4x games.   That said, I heartily recommend this title.

I could write a really long and detailed review, but if you want that, eXplorminate and Rock Paper Shotgun both have done fine jobs on that account. -Addicting space strategy opera-  This seems like the Galatic Civilisation 2-successor I wanted except it's real-time with pause. For the new player: Stellaris plays much like civilization in space including the dreaded 'just-one-more-turn-phenomenon'.  Features: Exploration, expansion, extermination (optional) or cultural/diplomatic win. Different ethics highly change your playstyle e.g. with xenophobe you only get mean first contact hails to select. In democracies the boss is selected among your leaders which mixes your staff around and so on. Context sensitive random event and crisis system, large scale galactic threat events. You can add planets to sectors under AI control so you don't have to micromanage your large empire. Indeed you have a cap for solitary planets. Game is highly modable. Space looks nice. No performance problems or crashes for me.  -minor bad things- There's an extensive tutorial but many conccepts are still cloudy (on the other hand there's also a wiki built-in) Some UI bugs and fighting with the controls and finding infos. Try to uplift a species for example. Pause is your friend here. If you play a lot events become repetative but more will be added later I guess. It could be even weirder but then I'm also reading Rhodan so take that with a grain of salt.  -mixed feelings- Games really depend on your neighbors and where you start as you're never far ahead in the tech/power race in this game even in 'normal'. If you want achievements you'll have to play ironman (only one autosave slot). Death and ruin can come quickly in space. You will take losses of beloved admirals and beautiful worlds. I personally rage quit after an 'ally' snatched a key planet away with a colony ship only 3 seconds ahead of my own colony ship. My best admiral started taking drugs then died ahead of her time.  TLDR; you can buy that, it's good.

After playing through countless 4X space games trying to re-live the enjoyment of MOO2 as a kid, finally there is a new version of MOO to play. Problem is, I found stellaris while waiting for MOOCTS to become less buggy, and more like MOO2..... and it turns out stellaris everything I've looking for in a 4X space game and more.   A Few Things:  The game gives you the feel of actually exploring out from your solar system. Surveying feels meaningful and enjoyable with storyline elements and technlogies introduced from discoveries.   The choices you make in creating a race have a definite effect on how your empire will grow and what problems you will encounter in your growth.  Space battles are enjoyable and actually performed in the same solar system view, in real time, as your empire management. No clunky transition or other players having to wait. Balance of the ship weapons and attributes could be adjusted a bit but I have no real suggestions on how to addequately do so.  Technology research feels meaningful, having standard, rare, reverse engineered, and dangerous technologies to choose from, each with there intrinsic benefits and risks is new to me. Technologies seem to impact game mechanics enough to really try and research and aquire/level-up scientists.  Having leaders, governors, admirals, and generals is a nice throwback to MOO2. Their benefits, stats, and effects on gameplay make them important and valuable... and dissappointing when they die of old age.  AI is enjoyable but could use some work. There are a few quirks that I'm sure are not attributed to be a race actually being programmed to be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Most of these quirks happen to be odd behavior and responses when trading/treaties/etc., a few others are in the actual war goals management and/or the behavior of attacking fleets during wartime. These minor AI issues do not reduce the enjoyment of the game enough not to buy it though.   Buy it. Enjoy it. Enough said.

The 4x space strategy genre has been waiting for this (or at least I have). The very scope of this game is amazing! Your stellar empire awaits expansion, as long as you can balance diplomacy, resource collection, military buildup, and science. This game makes it easier than it sounds.  The most exciting thing about this game is the potential that it represents. Upon launch it is a stable and enjoyable 4x game in the vein of Master of Orion. Indeed, Stellaris is already, upon basic release, near the threshold of usurpuing the title of the true successor of MOO (even while Wargaming works on their shot at an MOO successeor); all it will take is one or two DLC and the mod community, which I know is already hard at work, to transform this game into something really special. The MOO crown is within reach.   I'm playing vanilla right now and having a blast, but I truly can't wait for what is in store.   The game right now: 8/10. Just potential alone?: 10/10 I trust Paradox and its minions to do their thing. :)

This is a beautiful game. The graphics and art are incredible, but there's something beyond physical beauty here. The gameplay itself captures quiet solitude and shattering revelation. This game plays like the best episodes of Star Trek, the ones that make you feel quiet and small at the end. Every time you feel big and in control, you discover something new to make you feel insignificant again.  The game isn't perfect. It feels like the living project it is. It will get better over time, and some of the pacing inconsistencies and bothersome closeness of the midgame will get worked out.   But this game is already responsible for two of my favorite gaming moments of the year. Spoilers ahead:  1. The first time I came across an alien species. My science ship scrambled. I looked for stats or a description, or something to make me feel better. All I saw was a big scary number that was way bigger than my fleet could handle, and a big quesiton mark. And it was just sitting there, watching me, and then it disappeared. I wanted so badly to know what it was, and I was so excited to read about it when I finished that research project.  2. I was in steady mid-game stride. I had met all my neighbors, formed and aliance and some rivalries. I was in control, and building at a rate that would launch me past my rivals very soon. I sent a science ship out to explore the far side of the galaxy. And it suddenly disappeared. I paused and went looking for it. The last system it was in was a star with no planets, just a giant ring around the star. No sign of my ship. I unpaused, and a transmission comes in from one very angry, xenophobic fungus. His empire was larger, more powerful, and more ancient than I could comprehend, and he didn't like me one bit.   So no matter what else happens with this game, I want to thank Paradox for those two amazing moments. Those alone were worth the game price.

The game overall is extremely good, judging by the 113.5 hours I have logged in the first WEEK of the game being released. That being said, you will enjoy this game until you have to declare war on someone.   The warscore system is genuinely the worst war system I've ever seen in a 4x game, and I play A LOT of 4x games.   The game forces you to create 'war goals' which at first glance make sense, until you realize that you can only capture a few PLANETS (not systems) at a time, or form a protectorate over the enemy. You CANNOT just sweep in on a declaration of war and eliminate/capture an entire empire in one swoop. You have to 'liberate' or capture three or so at a time, and then accept peace. Wait like 10-20 years, and THEN declare war again, but usually that just turns everyone against you.   So for a game that says it gives you the freedom to create whatever kind of empire you want, it's true on that part. But what it fails to deliver on, is allowing you to actually carry that out. If you want to create an empire that is hell-bent on capturing and destroying everyone, you can create that, but once you have to actually begin taking over systems and empires, be ready to break out some painkillers for the massive headache that is the warscore system.  Additionally, most everything else people say is true. The UI can screw you over at times, and if it does it REALLY screws you over, but in my experience that has been very few and far between, if at all. The Federation system to me doesn't totally make sense, since I don't really see the benefit in forming one. (Not in a philosophical sense, but a gameplay sense. I don't see any in-game benefit with forming a federation anyway. Just more reason to pull out the painkillers.  To sum this game up, you WILL thoroughly enjoy this. Paradox has yet again created a stellar 4x game that again sets the standard for other companies to live up to. This is the way 4x games should be made. Like I said, I play a lot of 4x, including the complicated micro-managing ultimate 4x simulator Distant Worlds: Universe. This game is just a lot more fun to play. DW: U might be more of the 'classic 4x' game, but Stellaris is a game you can jump into every single time and enjoy your playtime. That's a game I'd recommend.

Stellaris, a game, I would say, is a mixture of other Paradox games like Crusader Kings and Europa Universalis and Sid Meier's Civilization games. You get to create your own race with its own ethics, morals and allegiances. In an ever expanding universe the selfish idea of humanity being alone in this vast and massive space becomes a myth as other races now meet with first contact and must look eye to eye with each other.   We may look at other countries on Earth with different cultures as strange and weird. Now imagine that you, an independent individual with freedom and human rights, meets with an avian creature with beliefs that it is better than you in every way and that there is no way to convince it otherwise. The idea of enslaving you and all other humans is the most common ideology for that creature and not just a very extremistic thought, it is a common tolerance for it and its entire kin. In Stellaris you must stand the test of time in an infinite and immortal universe and unite with likeminded people like humanity has done endless times in the past. But that was on Earth, now the political battlefield is between galaxies and races that look like birds, reptiles, cockroaches even flipping MUSHROOMS!   Conquer you enemies, study the arts of massive weapons of galactic destruction and find allies as ancient empires will remind you that you are not the first to rise nor the first to fall. And something worse is awaiting out there, something incomprehensible...   Stellaris is in my opinion a more 'easy to understand' Crusader kings or Europa Universalis. There are still many options and tabs that you need a basic understanding of, but it has been made so that you learn all of it by pressing buttons and looking around at tabs. It has been made more user friendly, although some might say it has become more casual.   There are many events to experience throughout the game and the first twenty hours, AT LEAST, are an endless amount of excitement as you progress, meet other factions, study new technology, new planets, anomalies... start a new war for liberation, conquest, humiliation or even political demands.   With patience, a fascination for science fiction or grand strategy in general, this game is certain to be a favorite.  Some of the problems I encountered with this game are sadly spoilers but whatever, they are part of the fright in this game.  10/10 - The hunt will come.... unite, please unite the universe, at all cost the alternative is far more gruesome than another war for unity.

I've played about 30 hours of Stellaris and so far I'm impressed.  The game let's you create a new species with different traits and governement types. When there are random encounters in the game you sometimes have options specifically for this or that trait. This makes the game even more enjoyable because with every trait you have the game can turn completely different from the last time you played it. Furthermore there's the research. Researching in Stellaris is different than most other 4X games, the things you can research all mostly random. For example if you started one game with early game good research it can happen that late game you will get some tech that really adds no progress to your game. What is also fun is the ship design and all the weapons you have. You can design your ships to be long-range or short-range, fully armored or fully shielded and there are far more things to explore with the ship design. What is also fun with the ship design, is that how smart you design your ship, how well your ship will do in battle. You can counter your opponents weapons or defense in the ship design. And then there is the different FTL systems you can have, each one with it's own pros and cons. This is only a small example of all the things you can do in Stellaris. But this all doesn't mean that Stellaris is a perfect game. It still has it's flaws, which is understandable because the game just came out. For instance my own race thinks that my leader is an alien. There are still some minor buggs and some things that are a little bit irritating, but most of them will should probably go away with the next few updates.  And then there's the multiplayer. Untill this day I personally haven't played any multiplayer with this game yet, but I sure am going to. The multiplayer seems a lot of fun and certainly a bit chaotic. If you would play with, let's say, about 20 players the experience will be much, much different than you'll have in singleplayer. There's all the alliances that can be shaped, federations that can be builded and wars that can be fought. I'm really looking forward to participate in one of these giant space wars. And ofcourse the other players are different than the AI. So you'll be having a lot of different, for example, trading offers than you'll have with the AI.  All in all the game is really fun to play and if you like these types of games I really recommend this game for you.  (14/05/2016)

I really wanted to love this game. I love the other Paradox titles I've played (EU4, CK2, Vicky2). My love of 4x space games goes back to my first computer (a tsr 80). You can imagine my excitement when I heard Paradox was doing a 4x game.   I went in knowing and having little problem with the Paradox model: release a fun if feature sparse game, then expand and add depth through dlc. I think with Stellaris, though, Paradox forgot the 'fun' part. I also feel that they took advantage of people willing to be patient for new dlc to expand features, and released something unacceptably incomplete. It feels more like a proof of concept of a 4x space framework, waiting for the game to be applied. That may not be completely fair, as the game is polished and stable, but every feature leaves me feeling like they ran out of time before being able to add the fun bits.  Speaking of fun, this is pretty subjective, but for me the galaxy is flavorless. Alien races and space monsters feel like placeholders. The alien races especially feel completely randomized and uninteresting. Ship art is also non-distinct or interesting. The spacemonsters feel like research pinatas, waiting for a strong enough fleet to bash them open.  Oh and now we come to my least favorite part of the game, fleets, or as I have come to call them: Giant Stupid Space Blobs (GSSB hereafter). Gather up all your ships, put them into a single fleet, and run around mushing smaller GSSB's - err fleets. There is no tactical decision. Splitting your fleet is just asking for an enemy to use a GSSB and mush your smaller fleets piecemeal. Also, in addition to lack of tactical depth, the animation of one GSSB fighting another GSSB is so awful that it isn't even accidentally humorous. A combination of techs and admiral traits and skill should limit the maximum fleet size, and that leads to another problem...  Techs. I love what they're trying to do here with a treeless system and having rares and super rares, I really do. For some reason though, it just doesn't work. I end up getting every tech by the end of the game, and no matter what I choose it really doesn't seem to have a big impact on the feel of the game. Every empire I play feels pretty much like any other empire I play. Again, no funsy.  As far as game completeness, I give you: The Sector. Sectors were an attempt to make large sprawling empires both more controlable and also expand more slowly by limited the number of star systems directly controlable by the player. I love the idea. But again, they missed on completeness and funness. As your empire grows, you will hit a hard coded limit (modable) on the number of stars your empire can directly control. Once you hit this limit you can transfer control of a star system to one or more sectors that you define. I was hoping these would be semi-autonomous entities similar in scope to EU4 client states. They could automate to manage and defend themselves as an independent vassal, while kicking up a percentage of their labor to the parent empire, maybe based on tax rate, tech, etc.  Unfortunately sectors are nowhere near this automated. They end up being an arbitrary mechanic with no real gain for the player. You can't even change the color of the sector on the map for easy identification. It's just a heartbreaking reminder of what could have been if the game were a little more complete.  Unfortunately, the heartbreak of sectors is a pattern that plays out over and over through the game experience. Early game is fun enough while you do early exploration and expansion, but any sense of fun and wonder disappears by mid-game.  I'll definitely be interested in what new patches and dlc add, but I'll most certainly be taking a look before I leap approach. I expected better of Paradox, and got let down.

Alright so, I'm your typical meat head shooter guy who screams over the mic while with his friends in TeamSpeak. I'm not the usual type to play games like this. But to be honest, this game sets its self apart from others like it in many ways.  The overrall diplomacy system makes up the bulk of this, making the game feel much more personal as the AI insults you, compliments you, and tries to push their agenda on you. Each empire feels like it has it's own personality. The best part of this is that if an empire that has liked you for a long time ends up disliking you, they don't immediatley turn to a bland, blind hatred. They still acknowledge your former relationship and let you know that they feel you have strayed from the light. The only thing that I felt was lacking was more advanced Vassal interaction.  The ship customization is great, it's not overly complex, but just complex enough to make every ship between empires unique. The research tree leaves something to be desired. The single player is excellent, but the multiplayer is where things really shine.  I highly recommend this game, especially if you have a group of friends that play it.

This is a *short* preview, unlike a comprehensive stuff I usually write. So, it's only based on couple of hours of gameplay - and why I even bothered to do this, I'll explain later.  RT 4x space simulation with 'pause', (in spirit) much like beloved MOO2. Meaning - there aren't TOO MUCH distracting, or even irritating stuff - one example would be a 3d research tree - all, restricted to what I saw so far, is done with a measure.   The space looks very alive and vibrant and with much to be discovered. Special events seem random and unique - think of ones in MOO2 (and don't think of some in... some other games). Oh, custom races are there too, in order to make gameplay more different each time. So are radically different opponents.  In short, I like this game so far. There were critics that 'mid- and end- game are boring and need to be worked on' - and devs admitted that - but, guess what - so are in Civ5. I never finished 3/4 of Civ5 games. And I play Civ-series for, like 25 years, or what was the Day 1 for the shiny, new Civ1 :)  Yet, Civ5 (the *good* Civ5, after 2 expansions) still leaves much to be desired for me. If this game is the same, well, it's on the par with Civ5 - and that means something. It's maybe even a new MOO2 - well, most of reviewer think it would be. I started playing after some patch that 'had a lots of promise', perhaps game was worse before, I wouldn't know. But I like what I see now. Even if it means hundreds of hours of semi-finished game (kind of 'this I would win for sure, if gameplay would be a bit more interesting, to motivate me for 20h more', or 'this is going badly, I *may* be able to pull it through since I play for so long, but... I'm not willing to play that same 20h more). Anyhow, same faults I forgave to Civ5. But with a chance to get better, which is something I can't say about Civ5.  Player will have to learn certain mechanics (not everything is obvious, there is a learning curve) - and from what I experience until now - it's worh it.   Hardcore 4x fan - try this, or wait for some more polishing. Up to you. People differ - I know some friends that used to say 'but I cannot control well all the space battles manually in Moo2, it's a game flaw', and some which used to say 'Imagine you'd have to *micro* all those 30,000 ships battles (in stacks, to be fair) in Moo1 - what a drag it would be'.   So, in numerous 4X games, the different 'X' were taken for main feature. So far, I like this proportion. It may change, though...  I'll update this after I had more experience... Anyway, looks good so far and if you're curious as me, perhaps you should buy it. I skipped so many 4x (and played equally much, just to be disappointed), but this one reviews had... something... that drew me to it. For how long, we shall see...

The events and and resulting stories are a nice addition to the genre, and the sector system (now that they improved the sector AI) is a good way to minimize micromanagement late game, but other than that there isn't much that feels different from other space 4x games.  So why do I give it a thumbs up? It's still a fun game, and even the people giving it thumbs down have logged 40+ hours. As it stands it is not exceptional, but paradox always improves their games over time, and I am looking forward to what this game will be in a year or two.

OK, this game is awesome. On the surface it seems like a very simplistic iPad tap and manage game, but you have to have an imagination when you play to fully appreciate it. You have the moral dillemnas, do you enslave a populace, or do you let them try to regulate their own political system of governance? What about lesser lifeforms and pre-warp civilizations, what about then? Do you let them live on their own, do you scan them and learn anthropology passivley, do you try to 'uplift' them and integrate them into your own workforce, do you completely purge them from your resources, or worse yet, enslave them and send them to the mines? That little bit won me over. It ignites the Star Trek geek in me. Are you the Federation, the Cardassians or are you some godlike precurser race viewed by them as gods? Hey we're just 'wormhole aliens' but if you want to see us as gods, then by all the means, add to our empire! The combat system reminds me of a cross between Settlers and Deadlock 2. You have the military might? send them in and a brief standoff occurs. You win or lose. They may send more at your borders, so be prepared to defend them. Military is wasted inside your borders. Lots of little popup mini-quests like pirates or heretic spawn within your borders, so have an inside fleet to deal with those. For the most part it's the simple age-old empire building of gather resources, build militaryl, defend and build and conquer. But what I love mosst about this game are the random events and the micromanagement. Kind of like Civilization III, but with a sector by sector grid of battles vs. the wider spread of ships and such. Some lets me down, some feels more fun. It's a fun game in any sense. What I DO wish, is that there were more victory conditions than mere expansionism and conquest. I play this game, and I wish I could be more peaceful and mercantile. I wish I could meet other races and form a federation. As it stands (and I may be wrong since I just bought it a day ago) is that you build power and sieze it. I want to be the good guy and uplift civilizations, make them my own, and I want to hash out alliances and trade empires, build more than destroy. That's my only beef with this game, it seems too straightforward kill them all, ala Settlers 7.

Probably the best entry into 4X real-time strategy in a long time.  If you like Sins of a Solar Empire - you'll like this  + Huge variety in ship designs & customise ship sections / weapons / components + PURGE HERETICS + Can create clone army + Can create droid army (who can rebel) + Can create synthetics (who can revolt) + Can genetically modify population to make super-humans + Research dangerous things (e.g. Artificial Intelligence) and have them blow up in your face + Passable graphics + Console commands available (SP only) + Interesting events in mid/end game which present a good challenge + Extensive research system + Choice to mico-manage planets, or just automate them by assigning planets to a sector  - Sounds effects aren't great - Music is just annoying (personal preference maybe) - Mid & End game do have some flaws (this is being addressed via patches) - Enemy AI is predictable - they spam corvettes (so you have to as well to counter that)  TL;DR  This interesting entry from a proven developer injects new blood into an otherwise stagnant genre. Worth the price tag. 9/10.

7/10  Whilst this game is not exactly CKII in space, or EU in space for that matter it does handle the Paradox formula pretty well. That being said, I'm not the biggest fan. Of the concept, yes. The way it works out, no.  As with other grand strategy games the play itself stagnates at some point. At the startup everything is exciting, exploring new system, colonizing new planets, developing new technologies. But at some point you're going to meet an other space empire that's either larger in economy or in military power. And that's were the Paradox ChooChoo train stops.  Up untill then you had a lot of fun, no problemo. But this is where all the games meet either their end in horrible defeat or a boring stalemate in which you try to equalize power.   Even though I try to finish my games, in the end I simply give up. For no other reason that it loses it excitement.   Though I have to admit that the point of giving up is after an hour or 10, so that means I've got at least a few good runs behind me.  I certainly recommend it to try it out, but if grand strategy (in space) is not your thing, you might want to spend your money somewhere else

Stellaris is an interesting new title among the mass release of strategy games as of late. Paradox Interactive, known for famed games like Europa Universalis IV and Cities: Skylines, seem to be testing gamers with a question rarely asked; 'How good can a space-strategy game really be?'  What do I mean by that? Well, when you think about it, space is big. Like   really   big. It's going to take a good system of trade and diplomacy in order to make such a large virtual galaxy feel alive, real, and especially interesting. It's no secret that Paradox is good at making historical stategy games, such as EU4 and CK2. But how would they convert that depth and enriching experience into not just a space theme - but an entirely made-up universe. No countries or empires to jot down, it's all either randomly generated or created by the player. So, how does it hold up? Well, here's my analysis, without the use of pros or cons:  * In my opinion, Stellaris is an almost perfect combination of the best strategy elements from both EU4 and Sid Meier's Civilization V. Diplomacy feels much like an in-depth version of Civ, while the structure of empires, federations, and vassals serves as a callback to Europa. The battle system feels perfectly blended between both games, but it's not perfect. The outcome of space battles almost always depends on how high your fleet power is, which is heavily influenced by your ship number and technology prowess. I'd say that the fleet battle system is good, but not the pinnacle of what a company like Paradox could achieve.  * Unlike most Paradox games (*cough cough EU4*), Stellaris comes with an unexpectedly detailed tutorial. I'm not a big fan of Europa Universalis or Crusader Kings myself, and yet the tutorial still got me in the right place without any difficulty. I'd suggest coming into Stellaris expecting Civ 5 depth but more detailed - even though there's far more to it than that, as you will no doubt see.  * Stellaris' customization/mods implements both creativity and individuality. There is a large gallery of choices for your species' appearance, empire, flag, and government. Workshop mods, especially, bring in a whole new array of possibilities. Stellaris has barely been out already, and there's already tons of coloring mods, a Warhammer 40k mod, new species, etc. Definitely worth checking out.  Overall, Stellaris is a more-than-solid game. It has both the depth desired by experienced players and the welcoming atmosphere sought by newcomers. This might even be the game that introduces some people (maybe even you) to the strategy game genre as a whole! Solid purchase; no regrets.  [Extra Notes...]  - It is not a turn-based game; the game moves in real-time unless you pause it or alter the speed. - I have yet to experience multiplayer, but I hear that it's very fun. Recommended for people buying Stellaris alongside a friend or two. - Paradox seems to be listening to player feedback. Let's hope that the great community continues! I really don't know what's going on in Paradox for this latest generation of games (HOI IV and this).   Stellaris is not a bad game... its just a lesser version of EU IV with a space theme. To be clear... I am not saying Paradox should not try new things. The issue with this game is the same issue that plagues Hearts of Iron IV, a farse of an UI. EU IV has perhaps the best UI of all Paradox games - it is relevatively easy to learn but offers all the numbers you could ever wish for. Stellaris on the other hand decides to make the UI at lot more simple and all the useful numbers have been replaced by vague approximations (superior, inferior, equivalent, etc.).   And that would be fine... If not for the fact that combat is almost entirely based on numbers. Granted, late game you're probably either already winning or already losing so a non specific approximation is probably all you need. Early game, 1 extra ship can be the difference between winning you first War or losing horribly - which is exactly what had happened in one of my games. In that round my enemy had one extra ship, something I could have never known since all signs (population, number of planets, etc.) seemed to have indicated that I should have been able to easily outnumber them.   And again this wouldn't be a problem... IF Stellaris had an actual combat system rather than a amoeba simulation. As much as I would love a combat system along the lines of a space Total War, the EU IV system would be enough - by which I mean that certian terrain (or in this case, certian tracts of space) have ups and downs to attacking or defending. Instead in Stellaris all you get is two or more blobs doing basic subtraction from each other with minor modifiers based on ship layout - which early game is close to irrevelent.   To sum it up... EU IV is just a better game. Hopefully Endless Space 2 will serve as a superior alternative this this once it comes out.

I'd love to be able to recommend this game, but unfortunately, I can't. It has a lot of good things going for it. It is pretty looking, for one. The emergent story-telling via events is a nice change from the usual bland 4X routine. There is a lot of data, but it is well-organized, and I never felt overwhelmed. I think it gives a good first impression.  Unfortunately, it suffers from some serious flaws. It is a slow game. Very slow. Expect to be playing it on Fastest speed for a lot of it, just to get to something to do. There doesn't seem to be as much meat to it as I'd like. The combat doesn't seem quite right, and though they show combat ratings, due to the variances of weapon types and defenses, those are very inconsistently accurate. It's not unusual to either be annihilated by or dominate similarly scored enemies. That makes battles 'fun'. The deepest flaw, for me, is the War Goals and War Score, which is something ported from their grand strategy titles. This is essentially a major constraint on a player's ability to wage war: you are required to pre-declare the goal of your aggression, build points by doing certain things, and then 'spend' those points at the end of the war to actually accomplish anything. This translates to taking over a dozen planets, but only being able to 'afford' to keep 1 when the war ends. It is as odd a system as it sounds, and it does not work in a 4X environment, in my opinion. The only up side is that your enemies play by the same rules, so players are less likely to be knocked out of the game in a single war. There are other more minor flaws and annoyances besides those, and an oddity with achievements only unlocking on Ironman mode, which seems needlessly anti-player.  Overall, it is not a bad game, but an ambitious, slow one with some critical flaws. It keeps a bit too much of its grand strategy pedigree, and suffers for it.

Looking at what Stellaris has to offer, it seams like an awesome game - and it is in many ways. I enjoyed playing it most of the time. However, several of the game's mechanics turned out to be either frustrating or only implemented to inflate the length of a playthrough. In this review, I will only talk about the negative aspects of Stellaris as of version 1.2.5.   Frustrating: Combat System  Ships built have to be integrated into a larger fleet as every ship on its own is a fleet, which inflates the fleet overview to a point where you're almost unable to find the correct fleet/ship. However, as part of a large fleet, there is no possibility to control individual ships within the fleet. Instead, only the overall fleet can be given orders.  Fleets themselves have a distinct combat mode. As soon as anything hostile is within combat range, the fleet will enter combat mode and engage. From this moment on, it is no more possible to control the fleet expect for giving the order to retreat. Moreover, the overall speed of the fleet is greatly reduced, depending on the ship type. As for the largest ship type, battleships, I found that their speed is reduced to roughly 1/12 of their usual speed. Since smaller ship types are faster, the fleet separates with the weaker ships in front engaged in combat and the larger, stronger ships in the back trying to catch up and not attacking at all. This effect is enhanced by the wedge formation of the fleet. Even for fleets consisting only of one type only the ships at the tip of the wedge will engage in combat, rendering the bulk of the fleet useless. The fleet formation cannot be changed. Thus, fleets are only effective when jumping onto other fleets outside a system's gravity well. This is frustrating as you will lose far more ships as necessary, especially when the opponent's weapons have a larger range such that your fleet has to move with slow speed to bridge the gap.   Gameplay Inflation:  The length of a playthrough is greatly inflated by three mechanisms:   Influence Points: Beside energy and minerals, influence points are a third basic resource required for colonization, establishment of outposts, recruitment of leaders, influencing elections, building certain structures, and controlling opposing fractions within your empire. Since influence is a resource, a certain amount is consumed by performing above actions. As influence rises only slowly and is greatly decreased by each existing outpost, the expansion of your empire is greatly hindered. Even if your empire is economically capable of sustaining a dozen new colonies, if you do not have at least 30 influence, you cannot establish a new colony. You will therefore find yourself often in the situation where you have to wait 10 minutes or so until you have accumulated enough influence for colonization - and then an other race claims the planet (occasionally). This mechanic of influence raises the question: Is there a higher entity that I have to please first before I can establish a new colony or even an outpost? Shouldn't this be determined by a player's economy?   Warscore: To declare war against another faction, you need to specify your war goals, such as e.g. liberation or ceding of a planet, or humiliation or vassalization of the other faction. Each of these demands has a certain value referred to as warscore. In a single war, you can only specify goals worth up to 100 points of warscore, which corresponds to about 7-8 planets that you can gain per war. After the war is over, a truce of 10 years is enacted. In practice this means that defeating a medium-sized empire of about 40 planets can take more than 50 years, corresponding to several hours. Even if your fleet is overwhelmingly more powerful than your opponent's and you could theoretically defeat your opponent in a single war, this is not possible. And again, this raises the question: Is there a higher entity that limits my actions?Why is it not possible to wage war as I want it?   Late Game Event **SPOILER**!!: In the later stages of the game, a certain event occurs that adds nothing to the game but greatly increases the length of the playthrough. I will not go further into details about this event.    Conclusion:  Although Stellaris has many awesome elements, the time required for a playthrough is significantly and unnecessarily inflated by several mechanics. In my playthrough of 50h for a medium galaxy of 600 star systems, at least the last 10h were only a grind towards victory - with occasional grinding periods throughout the game. And as the game has no 'Hall of Fame', achieving victory has no significance whatsoever. If you have no problem with inflated gameplay and unnecessary grinding, you may enjoy this game. Generally, I do not recommend this game.

Everything I ever wanted from a Grand Strategy game set in space. It's slightly more of a 4X Strategy game than your other main Paradox Titles.  This game is packed with depth in mechanics and features and is bound to add more through free expansion-DLC's.  From the very start of the game, you can craft your own unique Empire from a variety of traits ranging from Empire Ethics, Species types, Government forms, Hyperspace travels, and plenty of other unqiue ways to customize your faction.  The cosmos-theme of the game is extremely pleasant, the soundtrack is great, and the gameplay very addicting. The customization of your various star-ships based on hull-size with different types of weaponry, armor, and utility slots adds for a lot of strategic depth to how you structure your military.   You start with a single planetary system and the game-map can have up to a thousand solar star systems each with several planets (which you can terraform if they are not the correct planetary type to your species).  The ealry-game largely consists of exploration through surveyingn various star systems in your region controlled by 'Scientists', which act as one of the hero units of the game (others being Governors, Admirals, Generals).   Eventually, as your fledgling faction grows into the stars your mid-game continues technological development and comes into diplomatic contact with various other factions populating the galaxy. Being a sandbox strategy game, how you choose to play is largely up to you but conquest of your less amiable neighbors while military or trade alliances with others adds a lot of diplomatic depth that you come to expect from paradox strategy games.  The late-game is full of apocalyptic scenarios such as the technological singularity of synthetic revolution against biologicals, extra-galactic invasion, and some other interesting galaxy-changing scenarios that throws the mid-game-established balance of power for a loop.  Overall there's just too many mechanics to talk about here, from migrating individual 'POPs' (each with varying values that develop based on your species and others that inhabit your planets) to a wide array of technologies in a unique 'shuffle' system technology tree.   I fully recommend the game for it's price and even more-so it's on sale. If you're an avid strategy gamer this is one game you don't want to miss out on.
Even if you're new to this kind of game/genre, if you love the concept of colonizing space and the 'final frontier' this is a must buy for you.

TL;DR: Game is worth buying if you're a fan of 4X or other Paradox games. If you aren't, it's probably easy enough to get into but may not have lasting appeal. Perhaps wait for a sale or a few patches to add more content.  PRO: - Compelling early game exploration and expansion gameplay. - Interesting and viable systems for managing multi-species empires through several different approaches. - Tech system is, at least to me, a welcome change from traditional tech trees. - Combat and ship design add a lot of potential depth to the normal grand strategy combat (but see CON section). - Lots of opportunity for creativity and emergent narrative.   CON: - Midgame feels somewhat sparse. There aren't many events and the AI is a bit on the passive side, so you mostly tech up, fight wars on your terms, and backfill planets you haven't already settled. - Faction system feels very barebones. It has great potential but doesn't represent any serious threat to your empire in its current state. - Combat is not exceptionally well balanced. While ship designs have a lot of potential, there are clearly optimal builds that can let you dominate even the strongest empires.

It's like Endless Space and Crusaders Kings had wild, mechanically complicated sex and spawned this little bundle of timesinky joy.  Stand Out Features: Realtime 4x gameplay that doesn't overwhelm those more accustomed to turn based affairs. Beautiful art and music that matches the alien atmosphere. Crazy levels of depth in the management of your space empire (manage your colonies, edicts, government leaders, policies, ship design, ground armies, naval fleets, diplomatic relations with primitive and rival alien species, technology and I'm pretty sure I'm missing at least 3 other aspects to micromanage). Narrative elements jazz up the traditional 4x gameplay, turning every new game into a miniature story.  Pros: Aforementioned depth (Cannot be oversold. Compared to many other 4x games, there's just so much more to do in this one). Variety in the leaders allow for different gameplay experiences. Has that 'one more turn' allure of similar 4x titles. Solid and clever writing.  Cons: Volume of different mechanics to internalize might be overwhelming. Tutorial leaves out several mechanics that you'll quickly learn are quintessential to your success. Some mechanics are a bit soft and may leave you scratching your head to figure out why certain things played out the way they did (looking at you fleet combat score). Game will require hours of your time and probably some independent research to fully immerse into.  Would Recommend To: Fans of the Endless 4x franchise games, Crusader Kings 2 players looking for a little more gameplay, Civ 4 fans who felt Civ 5 was too much of a streamlined experience. Fans of Sci-Fi games who are not intimidated by a steep learning curve.

I really want to like this game, but it's just awful at providing sitational awareness - i.e. using in game tools to help the player keep track of what's happening in their vast empires. There are so many ways that the game fails to keep you aware of your empire that you're constantly clicking around and I've found i have to keep a note pad next to my keyboard to write things down that should be available in game. Here are a few examples:  1) Remembering things you discovered - You'll often encounter points of interest - early tech species, anomalies that you should study further, etc. Oftentimes you can't do anything with these right away and will want to come back to them later. The game doesn't track these for you well or give you an easy way to review things that you have already discovered. Again, better keep a notepad handy. There is a Situation Log that does track some things for you, but for some crazy reason it only tracks certain types of items and not others.  2) Knowing that you're being attacked - the game autopauses for some things like 'you discovered an anomaly' but, crazily not for things like 'your home planet is under attack' or 'your scout ship is about to get smashed'. Glad I'll never miss an anomaly, but I'd sure like the game to also pause and call my attention to the fact that one of my planets is getting invaded.   3) Tracking hostile encounters - if you encounter hostiles in a system you can click on that system and see the strength of the hostiles while your ships are there. If you don't click immediately and physically look at it before your ship runs away, all you get is a 'there are hostiles here' with no indication of strength. If the hostiles move, that 'hostiles here' marker stays until you can see the system again, so there's already an awareness that the info could be out of date. So why not show the strength of the last known contact?  4) Starbases - starbases are you main hubs for activity in the game. You build ships there, you rally defenses, but they don't, amazingly, show up on the map view. You have to remember where you built your bases and to access them you have to click on the nearby inhabited planet and from the planet screen, click on the base. Later in the game when many of your planets are in Sectors, you can't even modify your planets anymore, you're only managing the bases, yet the bases are still invisible on the map and you still have to click through the planet.  This game has a lot of potential, but a game designed around managing space empires should be better at helping you track the key things you should be managing / interacting with. At first it's only an annoyance, but as the game progresses, it just becomes painfully obvious that the designers didn't focus enough on situational awareness.

If You like real time stratergy and scifi you will love this game. I particularly like four of the main aspects of the game.   Tech, unlike most games does'nt have a set tree or web it is random and the more you specialize into something the more techs from that area will come up. e.g. when playing as a religious militant race you are likely to have psionic weapons come up as a choice to research, but as peaceful scientific race you are more likely to get a scientific boost tech like administrative AI which reduces research speed by 5%. overall this science mechanic is more realistic and is a refreshing change to games where you have a set tree that encourages rushing to techs.  Exploration is really fun with the game heavily rewarding those who explore and expand quickly, these are core aspects of 4x games altogether and it does not let down in stellaris. The different anomalies you find can give distinct advantages to science, military and political power. in one of my games I recovered an alien frigate at an anomaly and was able to use it to my advantage in an early war, but also in the same game my scientist personally went to inspect an anomaly and died causing me to mis out on some early exploration. The exploration in stellaris is engaging as the risks and rewards can very important to your growing Empire/Oligarchy/Republic...  The Questlines are, in my opinion the cherry ontop of the cake with stellaris. They are well thought out and are very important in game. like the anomalies they give a distict advantage and also give the player smaller goals to aim for other than total galactic dominance. The questlines are also relatable today and aren't some far fetched future plot that is uncomprahensable. This was show when someone changed 6 words in the quest log and turned the underground civilisation quest into something donald trup could have said to justify his wall.  Lastly the race designer is and will always be my favourite part of stellaris. The amount of ways you can tailor your race and government to your playstyle is staggering and the amount of time people have spent developing intricate backstores of how the currrent Grand Emperor got into power of how the communists took over earth inspires me to create my own races with backstories. The Race designer reallly adds alot to stellaris and is easy to use, this puts it infront of other strategy games like Civilisation where you have to rely on mods to get close to what you want.  Overall this is the best scifi strategy game I've played since 2k and firaxis released their version of Xcom.

Ok, so I've been playing this for a while now, and I can honestly say I'm impressed. Firstly, I use a top range LAPTOP from just over a year ago, so around the standard running power for most PC's, and definetly NOT a gaming PC, and the game runs almost perfectly on the largest map, just a slight drop frames late game but nothing really noticable. And for those that are maybe a little pushed for specs, there are also ways of turning the graphics down, though unfortunatly its not in the in-game settings just yet (there is a tutorial in the guides to show you how).  To me this game seems like a cross between Sword of the Stars (the first one, my all time favorite and one that I compare ALL 4x space games against) and Sins of a Solar Empire, combined with the experience of a company of reputable Grand Strategy games. The game is however not without its faults, namely research lacking a tech tree as you 'draw' 3 choices each time you complete a tech, plus I would also like to see more weapon types/weapon graphics entered into the game, as well as trade, both amongst your own planets and that with friendly civilizations (maybe even include a specific trait that increases friendly relations with those your trading with)  Overall though I've found the game addictive as it lets me play my own way, with huge customisation all around, from ship visuals and ship setups, planet names, goverment types to empire stats and rulers, plus has a decent ammount of replayability, as with every government comes a different choice in both diplomacy and research, for instance I've mostly been using Millitaristic Research Dictatorships so far, whos approach to reseach is either 'lets shoot it then study it' or 'we don't have time for this' whereas more.. peaceful governments would be likely to study it from afar, leading to different research techs to study (alongside the usual 3 random techs, and these dont dissapear till researched either). Also included is a 'sector' system, meaning that you can (actually, HAVE to) set certain parts of your Empire into an AI controled sector of space, thus freeing you from the duty of having to micromanage 50+ colonies late game. The game also works very well with the workshop community, so for those thinking the game needs more they can find it there. Would certainly recomend this to anyone who likes both Grand Strategy games and Space, I know personally I have found another benchmark from which I can judge other space games with this one (alongside SotS).

This is the best 4X space game I've played in over a decade. Stellaris is like a tremendous breath of fresh air for a stifled and stagnant genre.  What makes it so interesting is that your population is not just another resource or set of stats, but truly central. They have their own social values, and keeping them happy according to those values is key to success. But those values can change and evolve and, of course, the other races have different values of their own. This makes things interesting when your population starts to get diverse as a result of conquests or cross-migration (yes, they migrate on their own too).  Paradox games are known for gameplay that generates interesting narratives. Thus, for example, an empire built on brutal war and enslavement can find itself embracing emancipation and reforming its ways as a result of internal or external pressures. If you conquer a bunch of pacifistic individualists and don't have the heart to genocidally exterminate them, then you either have to moderate your ways or learn to live with constant rebellion. If your powerful neighbors revile your treatment of your people, you might have to choose between easing up or risking a war against a coalition that you might not be able to defeat. But the choices are there, and that's what makes for such a compelling game.  It isn't perfect. The interface still needs polish and I've had some problems with troop transports. Nevertheless, even right at release it's already a huge amount of fun and brimming with potential for continued growth.  Good job, Paradox. I was very skeptical when this title was announced, but I'm glad to say you've exceeded my expectations. If only more studios would step outside the usual conventions like you have here, maybe people would stop talking about the death of PC gaming.

There are a lot of folks bashing the mid game of Stellaris, and while that's an absolutely valid criticism, I'd encourage those players to think of it in a different way. While the moment to moment management of Stellaris is closer to EU, it veers more toward Crusader Kings II in its goals. Mainly, that it doesn't really have them.  And at least to me, that's the point. You make your own goals in Stellaris. If you're bored, make it your prerogative to form a new alliance, or expand your borders, or set up a new sector. I totally agree that the game shouldn't expect you to do that, and that aspect should be criticized, but it scratches that 'make your own fun' itch for me.

If you liked Crusader Kings or Europa Universalis and love 4x games, you will enjoy this game and you will be hyped for the new stuff to come in their DLC. Hours upon hours of gameplay. They threw in some great stuff for late game play, including an incursion from another dimension. The way the game seemlessly integrates your ship names, leader names, and planet names into the 'minor' events is entertaining and well thought out. I can't wait to see more.   Paradox has again done wonderful work. I look forward to its successors and the DLC that is sure to open up new possibilities for play. If you don't know what I mean, check out EU and CKIII for more information.   Grade A work! Keep it up!

However overall I was pretty dissapointed, I was hoping for a lot more. The game is pretty much a hollow game right now. The foundation is there, but it looks like Paradox is just going to fill it up with expensive DLC over the next few years. I would not recommend this game to anyone right now...wait till they fix or tweak some issues first.

Stellaris is a game that will on the first playthrough engage and challenge you. Subsequent playthroughs become less engaging as you come to grasp how the different knobs and levers of governance work. The main issue is the mid-game- there is little to no content in terms of narrative or challenge. You are not facing financial ruin due to a sudden inflation rate, You are not quelling an uprising, or straight up secession apropos of sudden political change too quick to respond to, you are not dealing with terrorists, funded either by malcontents within or without of your borders, you do not have to deal with the continuous challenge of holding your empire together because of competing political blocks (irregardless of whether or not they have any say within your political system). There are no sudden disasters that require delicate bipartisan co-operation between uneasy borders. There is, in short, little to nothing to add more flavour to the game beyond altering the difficulty.  Fleet combat is a numbers game, technological research means nothing in terms of specialisation. There is no subterfuge. Nothing that really gives the 'strat' element to a 'grand strategy'. Even the win conditions are vague at best.  In short, its a game that has a lot of potential and I'm holding out for more, I recommend the game, because at its core, even with all my complaints, I still find myself looking at the clock and wondering where the hell the hours went.

Back in the old days - mid 90s - I was introduced to Master Of Orion II. I loved the game and kept playing it off and on until this year, 2016.   Enter Stellaris; In many ways the game feels like MOO2 refurbished and upgraded to a 2016 version. Stellaris is what I wish the new MOO could have been: The galaxy is large, the tech tree is laid out in a very nice manner, being more random than the traditional fixed tech trees - and also being dependent on your civilizations' ethics and biology. For example if you start with a scientific materialist ethic and a biology evolved for a tropical world your research options will mirror this: You are more likely to get options to research robotics than spiritually inclined civilizations and you are unlikely to get the opportunity to research colonization of planets with a climate far removed from your own. You are for example unlikely to quickly learn how to colonize tundra planets but more likely to colonize e.g. continental or ocean worlds.  What I do miss are: A more intricate diplomacy system. It is quite good as it is, but it doesn`t fit with the complexity of the game in other respects.  Spying and tech theft would be nice. For example when integrating a vassal empire into your own it would make sense for you to also acquire their technology. Some technology should also be acquired upon conquest of another empire.  There is very little control over what happens in battles. You send your fleet in to duke it out and control appears to be taken over by the AI. You control troop movements on the galactic or solar system levels, but not in a battle.  Still, the game is excellent and I would warmly recommend it to anyone who is fond of 4X games.

Wonderful game!  I bought this last night on a whim so that I could play with some friends and it blew me away.   I've always been a fan of empire building games like AoE and Civ, and even had fun playing SPORE. This game's gameplay is the empire building from Civ mixed with the real-time fighting and building of AoE. Now take that gameplay and pop it into a huge procedurally generated galaxy like that of end-game SPORE, and you've got this game.   Stellaris has deep strategic choice in how you accomplish your goals, and the Race builder allows you to build a race specifically catered to your tastes and/or lust for challenge. You can be a xenophobic fungal democracy from a tropical planet, or you can be an all-inclusive Avian divine empire from a continental planet. There's SO MANY WAYS you can go with it, it allows each playthrough to be different and exciting in its own way.   It takes a bit (maybe an hour or two) to get used to what everything is and what it does, but once you do, you'll start to being blown away by how much there is to do and how much you want to do it.

Stellaris is a cross between a traditional 4X game (Civ, Galactic Empires, AoE) and the Grand Strategy genre that Paradox reinvented (Crusader Kings, Europa Universalis, Hearts of Iron).  The latter genre deserves a bit of explanaton. PDX has a reputation for designing incredibly complex games in exhausting historical detail with a legendary learning curve and menu upon menu. But in space, there is no history, and PDX has tamed some of the complexity that puts more casual players off of their other titles.  What remains is still one of the deepest and largest space strategy games ever designed. It includes all of the traditional 4X elements like research, colonization, strategic resources, exploration, etc. But the game goes far deeper: from hundreds of beautifully-scripted random events that you may encounter in the dark corners of space, to endgame crises, first contact with civilizations that crumbled due to their own foolishness long ago, or meeting ones you can help take their first steps into the stars. There are in fact so many game mechanics that they cannot all be listed, but the AI singularity, genetic modification, fully custom ship design, internal politics, and complex cross-galaxy alliances are just a few. There are so many ways to achieve an objective, that there almost is never an obviously correct strategy for any goal.  Stellaris can be played competitively, and often is in random-match multiplayer. But where the game truly shines is in a more creative, role-played form of play. The species creator offers unprecedented freedom relative to anything you may have used before and most players create their own civilization with traits, personality, lore, forms of government, and more, many of which have complex and surprising consequences. You will find yourself becoming attached to your species and more concerned with its own goals and objectives, heroes, alliances, and story, than on conquering the galaxy. After all, a peaceful religious species is going to behave differently than a warmongering dictatorship than an anarcho-capitalist syndicate no matter the so-called victory conditions.  The single-player experience is very deep and complex, and offers a useful sandbox to study the game and try new strategies. AIs have very detectable personalities, from the ruthless militarist to the peaceful trader, religious fanatic, hermit kingdom, corrupt democracy, slave dealer, etc., and they will each evaluate your empire and its policies and actions according to their own ideals and morality.  While random-match multiplayer is possible, at an accelerated speed Stellaris takes on more of a StarCraft flavor. But the traditional way to play Paradox titles is tabletop-style, with an ongoing campaign at a pre-set weekly time over several months. Each group is a little different but may be very competitive, relaxed, diplomatically oriented, or story-focused in nature.  Not all is roses. The midgame is a little boring in timed competitive play. There are several annoying bugs that were missed in the QA process for a game this size. The UX is poor for hunting down that missing strategic resource across the entire galaxy. Some things are too automated, and some things aren't automated enough. And diplomacy is currently a little uninteresting, where 'uninteresting' is code for 'merely Civ-quality' from the grand strategy snobs who are used to far more complex mechanics than the usual stable of alliances, insults, and trade agreements.  The good news is that PDX has a storied history of continuing to develop their games for many years. Crusader Kings has some 11 expansions (priced around $10 on release and less after they go on sale) and is still actively developed in its fourth year. And each expansion arrives with a free sizable patch that adds many mechanics, refinements, and rebalancings even to the base game. The result is MMO-like continual development, but without the fixed monthly subscription. The next three Stellaris patches have already been announced, with 30+ additions tentatively planned in the next few months.  Already Stellaris is a bright star, easily surpassing Civilization, Beyond Earth, and Endless Space in breadth and depth of gameplay. It has not yet reached the pinnacle of strategy of Distant Worlds or Europa Universalis, but it seems destined to eclipse them soon.
