I have been excited to play Stellaris a few months before release and it's because I love roleplaying, especially in something so grand.  Stellaris lets you establish your own story with your empire. Do you help the survivors of a ship disaster? Will exterminate the species that is still in the machine age next to your home star, or will you nurture their progress and gain a new ally? All of these choices come with consequences and Stellaris doesn't let you forget them. The cherry on the top is that Stellaris generates a Sol system in every galaxy. This system can contain a destroyed Earth, where nuclear weapons have ravaged the planet and pre-sentient cockroaches now roam the wastes, or it can contain Earth in a multitude of states, such as during the world wars or at their discovery of FTL.   In the start, the game is amazing. The dawn of a new age has arrived and you must explore the surrounding systems to discover all in them. Habitable planets? Space drones? Black holes? Who knows! All systems have a history, whether it is a small asteroid collision with an alien craft 12 million years ago, or a tomb world that foreshadows the return of a big mistake. The game plays more like a story, with you itching to discover the next habitable world or anomaly.   First contact is especially exciting, as you find a ship of a unknown design, you must decipher communications and establish relations with a empire that wishes to build a federation or an empire that wants to exterminate all alien life in the galaxy. All the empires have personalities based on their ethos (individualistic, materialist, spiritualist, militarist, xenophobic, ect) that determine their behavior throughout the game. The Fallen empires are exciting too, with their superiority reigning over every empire in the galaxy. Will they awaken to fight a great threat? To unite the galaxy? Or to dominate it?   Stellaris is less about the gameplay (which is still wonderful) and more about the story. It creates a relationship between you and your empire and soon, you find yourself a part of a galactic community that responds actively.  With the addition of the Horizon Signal, it is a must get.

I am a big CK2 fan, so let me write this review from the perspective of and for CK2 player(s).   - Many similarities: you start of designing your race, ruler and homeworld much like the Ruler Designer (inc. trait points), the battle system is very similar (but now with space ship design), you will also find event chains much like those in CK2. Plus: blob to your heart's contenct. Also, you won't have many problems with the interface, the buttons are right there where you expect them to be.  - Appoint leaders much like you would appoint chancellors, stewards etc. And succession plays a role in the leadership too! Though not the kill-all-the-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥-nephews-and-marry-a-Viking kind of succession issues.  - It's less deep than CK2, by which I primarily mean no long-term thinking. Where in CK2 you somethimes had to keep track of 100 family members and plan your strategy for generations to come, in Stellaris it's more 'in the moment'.  - Naming stuff! If you're a fan of naming stuff, including people, planets, empires, ships, you name it (heh) - you can name them all!  - Idle waiting.... I major draw-back for many Stellaris players is that a lot of the game is spent waiting, at a certain point. Luckily for us CK2 players, we're used to waiting until King John the VII'th is finally of age and can marry the Pope's sister.  - Finally, CK2 was all diplomacy. This is a lot less powerful in Stellaris. There are fewer factors that can influence relations with other species/empires. Stellaris is more resource management than people management, so be prepared for that.   Final note: The (in)famous 'Can You Run It' website told me that absolutely no way I could run it. That's nonsense: running without lag at high graphics.

It's only going to get better. While this game does have potential for being excellent, it doesn't seem to be completely thought out and finished. There isn't anything glaringly wrong that should prevent you from buying it at some point. Just for the moment, it's not all there.  I will use a Not Recommended tag for now, only because I do not think Stellaris is finished yet. Once it is patched up, this review will change if it's good to go.  Here are the PROs that I found - The music is quite grand and fitting. I never felt like I needed to disable it. - The nations and species are diverse. You'll find species based off of humanoids, avians, bugs, and so on, and those species break further into sub categories. In a galaxy, the main empires will mostly not be alike the other. You can potentially find a primitive race that seems to be similar to an existing empire, but that's a believable idea anyway. The nations themselves will be fairly diverse as well, from democratic soceities to xenophobic nations of faith to reclusive nations. -The options for elimitating micromanagement are a good idea (more on that below) -The beginning of the game is full of exploration, quests, and danger. You'll start by exploring your system and the neighboring system, finding anomalies and resources on other planets. These discoveries can also lead to quest lines that reveal more about the galaxy, such as a story line of a long lost race. - End game crisis is an excellent idea and allows for a legitimate ending instead of 'Ding, got conquest victory, done.' - It has space cows.  Cons: - This is galaxy full of implied activity. However, if you are looking at everything, it's quite dead. Capitol planets, for example, have absolutely no visual activity around the planet despite being potentially a galactic center for commerce. There should be visual elements added to increase the feeling of a large empire. For example, civilian and trader ships that you cannot interact with moving from sector to sector. - Horrendously dumb AI. They will send colony ships everywhere without actually using them, or transport boats with foot soldiers that never land. This also extends to AI used for determining pop migration. On a recently conquered planet (inlcludes the -25% happiness debuff for recently conquered), despite being super unhappy with the situation, will williningly migrate to a planet controlled by the conquerer. - You cannot 'fail' a first contact, it just happens. When another species or nation meets you for the first time, how that interaction will play out is already decided. They either like you already or they do not. There is no challenge in first contact, and it ends up being a chore. This is because the decision of the other nation party is decided by the traits that you picked at the start of the game. For example, a democratic nation will start off as friends with another democratic nation, whereas slave nation will be hated by the freedom nation. -Your responses to primitive civilization events (such as reaching the Steam Age) is almost literally 'That's nice.' There is no other purpose. -If a primitive civilization exits the early space age and reaches your level, they instantly are granted the entire system if you do not already have a colony or frontier outpost. This inludes any mining/research/observation you have in that system. The primitive civilization already appears to be very familiar with the galaxy, as there is absolutely no benefit to being the first one to contact them. There are uplifting mechanics you can do, to manipulate the civilization to get to the space age faster, but what if you do not want to meddle with their progress until they reach the stars? - While the end game crisis is an excellent idea, it is not executed well. For example, I ran into the robotic uprising crisis. This did not happen within my borders since I refused to take on robotic pops. However, my neighboring federation ally did. However, that nation took absolutely no steps to retake the systems or even prevent it from getting worse. In my efforts to free the nation from the robotic overlords, I tried to give systems I liberated back to the ally, only to find that they then went back and put robots back on the planet and lost it again to the uprising. Furthermore, I only wanted to get rid of the robots, but since this is the same thing as taking over a planet by hostility, it also destroys the planets atmosphere (for example, a tropical planet will become a tundra planet). This made any further attempts to free my ally to be not worth the effort. - Sector management is almost punishment for making a large empire. The idea is that it will do all the planet management for you, but it quite honestly has no clue how to do that. You just have to cross your fingers and hope they do contribute to pop happiness. I am ok with a system to manage multiple planets at once, but I also need to be able to control that system easier. - Upgrading ships needs to be reworked. It is currently not beneficial to upgrade fleets as the amount of time to upgrade them is basically a rebuild. - Foot soldiers need to be able to be healed while in orbit of a friendly planet. You have to land armies on a planet in order for them to heal. This is tedious when your army is larger than the planet can handle. - Trading Star Charts causes you to not see the discovered primitive civilizations until they achieve the space age. - Democratic nations need more customizations. I made the mistake of supporting a presidential canidate only to then discover that this causes the leader to never lose an election and ended up serving 11 presidential terms before finally dying of old age. There needs to be controls on how the democratic elections are run. - There is no more space exploration once you discover a few nations around you. Unless if you negotiate border access with them, you are boxed in. If you do become friends with them, they will spam you with Star Chart trades to the point you've 'explorered' the entire galaxy.   Stellaris is also quite buggy for the moment. Here are some: - I had an Admiral that reached 186 years old, with a death chance of 104%. He is still alive at this time and leading my main fleet. - If a system changes hands while you cannot see it, you enter the system to find stations in space with no owner and tells you to research an alien race that doesn't exist. - If you trade star charts with another civilization and they discovered a primitive civilization, you can't see their civilization, only the fact that they exist on the planet. If you try to put an observation post on the planet, you cannot control it as it says you do not own the observation post. - IF another nation also has researched the ability to put Xenos in positions of leadership to the point of being the face of the nation, the Diplomacy screen will refer to them as the wrong species, causing confusion. For example, it will show a human as an avian migratory flock if a human is their president. - If you play as the United Nations of Earth pre-made nation, you may find another Sol, planet Earth, and humans, all identical to your own. I ended up needing to rename this new Sol and Earth just to avoid confusion. - You may accidentally put a Pre-Sentient species in control of a system. If you conquer a planet, a faction of pre-sentient beings may appear at which point you can grant them independence, even though they are marked as pre-sentient. I had a nation of Snakeoids put an embassy on my world even though I'm pretty sure they cannot read, speak, think.        There isn't anything wrong with the idea behind the game. I think it's all there, it mostly needs tweaking. I'm sure I will be seeing a lot more of this game some day. For now, I'll wait for the next major patch.

Ah... Great game for many reasons listed in all the positive reviews stated here. Let me start off by saying that I agree with most of them.   However, I have to give this game a negative review and NOT recommended it. This is why this game didn't work for me, and if you can relate, may not work for you, even though there are a lot of positives, the two following reasons are why you should save your money:  THE FIRST REASON IS THE TECH TREE: The tech tree is not a tech tree per say where you can plan your empire's technology by following a strategic path determined by you, like in other similar games we are accustomed to. The tech tree in this game is like a deck of cards, where each cards represent a technology, divided into three different stacks. Each turn you get to choose from three different options within these three stacks. Sometimes you get rare cards (rare techs), and the deck is 'stacked' in the sense that for example, at the begining of the game, the likelyhood of you getting critical required techs is much higher, so that you do not start at a disadvantage. The logic behind this from the developer is to have every game feel like a different one, since you can not choose your techs, but must work from the random draw of cards. The reality is that makes the game less fun. Let's say you want to play your empire a certain way, for the sake of this example, you want to play it as an economic pacifist nation. You need to improve your hydroponic farms to improve food output in your colonies. In previous type games with a regular tech tree, you would research the path that leads to the technology strategically required for your empire. With this system, imagine you keep getting military related technologies in the draw. You are therefore OBLIGED to research military technologies. You can't improve what you strategically had planned for your empire, therefore you are forced to adjust and end up not being able to play your empire the way you wanted to. The whole point of a game like this is to be able to create something you want, and to have success doing it. If you plan a strategy, but the game doesn't give you the techs that go with that strategy, you must change it. Bottom line is that you end up playing a way you didn't want to, and that's no fun. At least it wasn't for me. There are other ways to create a challenge, I feel that not letting you go the direction you want to (which does indeed create a challenge, but an artificial one) is not the way to do so. It’s like creating a challenge in Mario Bros where Mario sometimes doesn’t jump the way you want him to. Yes the game is harder, but is it fun? I certainly don’t think so. I like to roleplay my empire, and I like to decide which way it goes, not have the game do it for me.  THE SECOND REASON IS YOU ARE FORCED TO RELEGATE CONTROL OF YOUR COLONIES TO THE AI: Yes you read that right. You can only control a certain number of colonies (4 or 5!!!!) and the rest have to be put into sectors, and given to the AI to control! Yes you can give general direction to the AI, but you can NOT micromanage your empire if you wish to do so! You MUST relinquish those colonies. In other games the options is there as a convenience, when your empire gets too big and you wish to focus on your fronts. Then you the player, can decide if you want to or not. In this game, this is forced on to you, which is a very strange decision that I do not understand. I don’t see how in a strategy game this is something the player would want.  These two factors, which are both things that remove choice from the player, are game breakers for me. It means that my empire is not truly mine to control, and all the other great features just makes these two annoyances even worst, because I realise what a great game this could be, if only the game would let me rule my empire the way I intend to.  Hope this helps.

In it's current state, Stellaris is far too rough to be great. It isn't bad, it just isn't really meeting expectation for me.  First, the midgame drags just incredibly. Once you stop having things to explore, or at least a point to exploring them, the universe loses a lot of it's charm. To add to this, quite a few of the event chains i've run into have been bugged and are uncompletable or uncontinuable past a point - I have completed the objectives, but they just sit unfinishable in the event log. Past the first 150 years or so, the game slows massively (just processing time-wise) on the default-sized galaxy, adding to the feeling of drag.  The AI isn't aggressive at all, or at least hasn't been in my game, so I have only been in wars I have started. All fleets seem to be largely the same speed, and the retreat option is extremely powerful, so actually chasing down a fleet that uses the same travel method as yours is almost impossible. My transports have also been unupgradable, so while my fleet's warp ranges have increased, I can't actually bring troops to land on the planets I bombard - all I can do is chase down every military ship and station until the enemy surrenders, which is painstaking and a bit boring.  The UI is very clunky in places - the 'e' (galaxy map/system view toggle key) only works properly if you have the system highlighted 'perfectly', so I often end up snapping the camera to somewhere that feels utterly random. There is no way to center the map on a fleet in the galaxy map, only in the zoomed/system view, after which you have to rely on the toggle key to hopefully leave you still looking at your fleet. The research screens do not indicate when you have more than 4 research options very clearly, so it is very easy to miss until you get into the habit of trying to scroll 'just in case'. There is no event log, so it is very easy to miss things if you accidentally clicked through something or want to remember what just happened. It does not seem possible to change the notifications at the top of the screen like it is in other Paradox games, so there is no way to add pauses on important events, nor is there any way to hide the dozens of 'hostile fleet detected' popups during a war whenever you detect a science ship or single corvette, apart from just clicking them all away.  I trust Paradox to make this extremely good in the coming months, but I regret trusting them enough to preorder this. It needs a serious dose of patches before it should be honestly recommended.

Disclaimer: I have roughly 80 hours in this game prior to someone buying it for me on Steam, because I forgot to remove it from my wishlist. The 7-8 hours I have on record are not the full extent of my experience.  I love this game.  Don't buy it.   The game uses only a single CPU core to calculate everything. There's a lot of things to calculate. It's a realtime 4X game, after all. This on it's own would not be an issue, however, it does severely limit the amount of things you can process without it slowing the game down to a crawl.  And it does. Often.  Currently, the game has several crippling performance issues, caused not only by it's engine not having proper multithreading, but several problems from the game's AI, such as sectors shuffling pops endlessly. Which, by the way, the devs promised to fix by release. They didn't.  Currently, on my system that far passes by the requirements, I can only play the game at about 20 frames per second, with the game's simulation speed slowing down to at least 1/5th of it's speed. While the game is definitely not unplayable, playing on Fastest in the endgame pretty much results in playing it on Slower. Core 5 is taxed 100%, while all other cores are entirely unused.  The only way I could get this game to function at a reasonable speed is by overclocking my CPU to over twice it's capacity, up to 6.8GHz (!!!), however, unless you're cooling your system with  liquid freaking nitrogen , this is not feasible.  Do not buy this game in it's current state, if you can't put up with this. I can, and I'll suck it up, because I love the game that much. But ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥it, I can't recommend it to anyone.  Note how I have not actually talked about the game itself. Have you played a Space 4X? You've played Stellaris. The genre is slim pickings, and quite frankly, in the current state of the genre, Stellaris is the most well designed one in terms of theme, aesthetics, and gameplay.  But it runs like ♥♥♥♥. And it probably will continue to do so, until the devs finally decide to retire this old, awful engine, and make one from scratch that can actually multithread.  If you can stomach this, play it. If you can't, stay far away.

40 hours in a single game and despite my federation covering about 50% of the galaxy with our combined borders, and every empire not within the federation being a vassal of either myself (mostly) or one of the other members, THERE WAS STILL NO VICTORY! I literally couldn't declare war on anybody and if I wanted to leave my federation to take over the other members, I'd need to wait a 10 year truce...   There is a lot wrong with this game, but I think it boils down to 2 main points.    The AI is as dumb as a doorknob    There is barely any content      The AI:  So often there are AI ships stuck in a system not moving anywhere, even when that empire is under immediate threat. If you click on the fleet, it will show that it is beginning to warp to another system, but then tries to warp to a different one, and it sits there flipflopping between the two. I managed to defeat my first major battle, despite me being severly underpowered, because I exploted this by attacking two systems on either side of the empires main fleet.  When you declare war, every other empire within your control (including allys), 'look to you for wisdom'. By that, they turn your highest 'power' fleet into a deathball by following it with their entire army. This is so moronic that even if the enemies begin bombarding their planets, their main fleet will still follow you around like they are on a leash. Now, this is helpful in some circumstances. You can take out some much more powerful enemies when you have a few empires worth of ships all attacking the same target, but come on, it would have made much more sense to split up and attack some different targets, especially in the end game when you outpower everything.  God forbid, if you decide to join a Federation with your Alliance. It works by giving each member a 5 year turn at being leader. They get to choose who to go to war with and what the demands will be in the case of victory. When it came my turn I found myself declaring war on 4 lesser empires just so we would still be at war for at least part of their turn, because in the 100 or so years that I was in a Federation, I think we declared war on two other empires, and had them declare war once on us. In all 3 circumstances, the AI leader would set the demands to liberate a few enemy planets. The problem with this is that the liberated planets still take a lot of work to befriend, so it's usually easier to just declare war on them and cede them like the AI should have done in the first place. Liberating planets is literally the dumbest move you could do in your war demands as it just prolongs an already severly drawn out game.   The Content:  I probably spent 2/3 of this game on the fastest speed setting,  AFK , as I waited for things to happen. The first few hours of the game are pretty interesting, your borders are under immediate threat and you have a lot to get done, but after that, basically nothing can threaten you. There are a few quests that pop up, and   an alien race will invade at some point  , but they are few and far between and even the few that I did get were pretty much bugged and uncompletable. A game where I sit around waiting for things to happen (and I can't make things happen because the terrible AI doesn't know how to control a federation when it's their turn) is not fun to play at all.  All in all, this game feels like it should have been early access and given another few months for playtesters to give the devs something to work on.

Stellaris promised (in a parody of Donald Trump) to 'Make Space Great Again'.  Sadly this promise, like Trump's, is one that is full of hot air, because Stellaris is a remarkably bland 4X game. I am a huge fan of Paradox and their strategy games. I have never played any game with the feeling of depth and stories unfolding that Crusader Kings 2 has. So it is all the more sad to see this game lack anything like it.  -The choice of species is entirely cosmetic, and except for humans, males and females look exactly the same. -The diplomacy is static and unengaging, mostly consisting of trying to make the aliens like you better (which is damn hard unless you happen to share political traits with their civillization). -The 'storytelling' (which Paradox usually excel at) consists of a few random events. -The tech research consists of 'pick one of these three choices and hope you get somewhere good'  I could go on and on, but to sum it up: the game lacks depth, variation and most importantly, soul.  Now, this being Paradox, I know that they will of course roll out DLC's that will improve the product a lot. And there are already a lot of great workshop mods out there, but without a complete overhaul, this will never be 'CK2 in space'. If what you are looking for is a generic space 4X with great community support but not much story though, this is for you. Otherwise...wait for a DLC that will make it worth the price.  Score: 4 / 10

short review: shallow rpg and rng point and click adventure.  I didn´t expect much and was still disappointed.  You want to set pause/popup/message options? Well, buy another game. There are basically no options at all (besides turning the music on and off) - no reassigning of fastkeys etc. .   The ui is a mess. for example: there is a list of all the other empires. I would expect to get to the diplo screen by clicking on one - nope. You have to search the map and click your way through - thats 90% of the gameplay, It´s a new genre: click´n´search. No ledger, no mapmodes. You want to know, if there are unhappy citizens in your empire? Just click on every planet. Whos allied to whom? click, click, click.  The ui is poorly designed, especially when you consider, that it is made by paradox (lot of experience in strategy games) and not by some 12 year old kickstarter newbies.  All about luck. Your leaders traits influence the game big time. Your leader has weak traits? bad luck. Your starting system has no resources? Too bad. You dont get the tech you need? oh well (it took 35 years, before i was allowed to build bigger ships). Your explorer fails all the time, even with 93% success rate? nothing we can do.  Diplomacy went back to the basics. You like me, you good. I want fire, ugh. Really wonder, how they couldn´t be embarrased by that poor performance. Worse than the original civ.  The 'discovery' missions are 99% useless, a complete waste of resources, if you dont know, which to pick.   You will spend the first few hours micromanaging your planets, explorers and constructors (click, click, click). No production chain, or a 'build-that-as-soon-as-there-are-enough-resources'. Assigning sectors doesn´t really help. I gave them (3 different sectors) the task to earn energy (credits, money), gave them resources to help them grow, and they built spaceports. After that they upgraded the spaceports. Good job.  You get punished for success. The more population your empire has, the slower you tech up, for example. Which makes perfect sense, because reasons. You´re getting punished for exploring. You just want to expand and discover and don´t want to focus on military in the beginning? Have some space pirates. You want to play without space pirates? Just go to the option menu and turn off the music.  In the endgame I was thinking: do i really want to spend resources and clicking on building another colony, when it wont help much, but seriously harm my tech? why would i want to fight that empire? The game doesn´t fell rewarding. It´s more like: 'great you achieved x, you really earned a kick in the nuts.' (some achievements are bugged, but getting achievements didn´t really help.)  There has to be some kind of AI somewhere, but it´s really hard to find. The game is way to easy, because the AI behaves like a toddler. Good thing they´re cheating resources and tech, otherwise the ai would destroy itself, before you´re even able to attack.  This game might be interesting for roleplayers, who want a very slow paced game, with a lot of pointless clicking. But it just isn´t a grand strategy game. It´s the incestuous son of ck and eu, hidden away in a dungeon, screaming: ESMERALDAAA, playing hide and seek with his own snot and loses.  So if you like clicking, but flappy bird is too fast paced, if you have been overwhelmed by the option menu of super mario world and really hate it, when any of your decisions have influence on the gameplay and you love gambling in online casinos, this is THE game for you.

There are many reviews already published here on Steam that praise the game so I will keep this review short.  Stellaris is, without a doubt, the easiest (grand) strategy game from Paradox to date. It is a good thing because other games such as Europa Universalis IV, Hearts of Iron IV or Crusader Kings 2 can be a bit too difficult for new players. It is not to say that this game is easy when you are playing it on harder difficulties. Sure, it can be a bit wonky and sometimes AI acts a bit strange but overall Stellaris is still being polished and, knowing Paradox, will continue to be in years to come.  As with other major strategy games from Paradox, you are allowed to create and install mods. From a simple cosmetic mod to major total conversions and various fixes, balances - if vanilla game does not suit you and you are able to create or find a mod that changes this one, frustrating little mechanic... than it is as simple as pressing this subsribe button. Very easy and very helpful.  I am sure that many other reviews say what I have just said. It is worth repeating however as it is my belief that Stellaris is worth its price. Sure, when you have played it long enough you start to notice a lot of repeated events (planet discoveries etc.) and your performance of the game is getting worse with each passing decade but that is the nature of those games. If you can forgive those small nuisances than you are going to really enjoy Stellaris.

Stellaris is one of my favorite games of all time, and some of the reasons I enjoy it might not be the same for others. This is a recommendation, sincerely, but as truly fantastic and engrossing as this game is, it may well not be for everyone, for a couple reasons.  Stellaris is difficult to define even when compared to other games of it's kind. It bears the most in common with other grand strategy games, but is quite the departure, and at least marginally more acessible to the newcomer.  It is, essentially, a simulation of species, from the first steps outside of their solar system, to whatever future you make for them. Be it conquering and enslaving or seeking to form a federation for the ages, your options (and customizations) are vast.   Gameplay early on can be dreadfully slow, sending out your little science ship and learning more about your surroundings, but ultimately the second you colonize your second world, build your second ship, meet a neighbor, it starts to ramp up and doesn't stop. By the midgame you've got potentially dozens of planets, ships, surveying, each planet needing to be micromanaged into what buildings it has, all while desinging vessels to counter your neighbors.. it's a treat. It's a real time game, but much like FTL, the ability to pause is used frequently to stay sane.  It is, again, not saying this lightly, my favorite game of all time, and I shall be playing it indeed for the REST of all time.  The DLC in my opinion is skippable but also really highly enjoyable!

Stellaris is one of those typical Paradox Games in their early stage: You play it and are blown away at the beginning, discovering new elements of the game at every turn (I was extactic when i found out about uplifting). After you play 1 or 2 games, however, you notice the lack of depth and missing polish at every corner. Then you look to EU4 or CK2, and you know the game is gonna be great 2 years down the line, in fact, you can already SEE how good this game is gonna be while still playing this basic framework.  Every big patch is bringing new stuff to table and does not shy away from redesigning core elements, in my opinion so far for the better. While there is still a lot to do (my biggest gripe is still that endgame crises are not formal wars and thus the AI is unable to recognize them as enemies and doesnt do jack against the doomstacks of extragalactic invaders) I'm positive the game is only going to become better as time progresses.

This game has a lot of potential. That's usually what the majority of reviews comprise of, and to be honest I agree. It's a great base game, but in 2 years it'll be legendary. Just like the most of Paradox's game lineup.  Having played multiple empires with a variety of crisis events and endings, I've experienced the whole spectrum the game offers. It starts out exciting, then mid game it almost dies. Till the galactic crisis hits your systems, it's mostly an arms race to amass the largest military and declaring war on nearby nations. A peaceful or trader playstyle would be almost impossible I imagine.  If they could add civilian traders and other aspects of commerce and trade to the galactic economy like some of the mods in the workshop offer, it'd definitely give the player more activities to do during the dead silence of the mid game. I also wish they'd make the planetary building construction automatic.  All that said, I love the game. It was my first 4X game, but I've had experience in the RTS genre (Tiberian Sun) that drew me to this game. My overall recommendation is it's a great game, but if you're used to another fully fleshed out 4X, then wait for a year or two when they have time to release updates, new content & DLCs.

I've spent all day playing this game. It's addictive. There's a civilization creator that allows you to create your own civ, to a degree. You can be space faring monkey xenophobes who praise Cthulu (not really but you can be spiritual!) whom have no regard for anyone else, or a reptilian anthropod that lives in a desert climate... or an arctic or even a tropical. The choice is yours.  The game is simple enough to learn, but in depth enough to hold ones attention. Its combat is simple, point and click. No need to micromanage abilities. All you have to do is ensure your fleet is well armed and that they can take a punch.   The diplomacy is pretty simple, similar to that of civilzation but less 'I'LL MURDER YOUR FACE FOR NO REASON!' It's been handled well enough for what the game is.   Graphically the game is simple, but beautiful. Zooming in up close to ships and planets reveals a lack of high quality graphics, but what were we to expect? When viewed from afar it is beautiful.   Multiplayer is well handeled. I've tested it with 3 friends. We chose to play in a clustered start... Me and one friend ended up right next to eachother in a spiral 4 armed galaxy. The other ended up on the other side getting juked by all the aliens.   The game is a real time strategy, there's no turns. You can slow down, pause, or speed up the game. It works great in single player, and from the limited experience I've had in multiplayer it works just as well. Though I can see the hassle of dealing with people who pause the game every 30 seconds. In multiplayer getting a pop-up doesn't pause the game.  The inability to alter the control scheme is a bit unfortunate, but it is simple enough that you don't really need to. The only thing I found that I wanted to do was change the pause button from space to my mouse.  Research is quite unique in the way it has been presented. There are 3 types of research, each with a large amount of tech trees. However being able to research a specific tech tree all comes down to chance. Each researcher is presented between 3-whatever choices. Typically three. Each choice is randomized after a tech is researched. This requires the player to pick and choose which tech is more important to them. Do they go for the research that allows them to build destroyer sized ships? Or do they instead get defense stations?     10/10 would pre-order again. I don't see myself playing anything else for awhile. As I paly the game I may change my recommendation, but as is it's a thumbs up. Get it, the price is worth it.

I love this game, I really do. But it's not because of the awesome ship designs(which still REQUIRE a coloring feature) and the various species you can play as, but rather because of the little ways it brings the immersive part of your brain to life. If you try to play this in a roleplaying fashion, and not in the 'I named my plant species The Weed Bros lol' fashion, then you'll quickly find yourself coming up with snippets of everyday life in your homegrown empire. You'll think of all the conspiracy theorists on that frontier planet after your leader is mysteriously reelected for the fifth time(even if you just really need his fleet-building trait), you'll picture grand parades as your rookie admiral(who has the arm-chair commander trait) leads your fleet to victory and you'll be thrusted into a darkened conference room next to your fellow alien peers as they whisper about 'purging' those troublesome fanatical spiritualists who have been protesting on a planet rich in minerals vital to your fleet construction(causing literally no gameplay hindering effects other than a differently colored happiness bar).  I've never actually finished a game, my computer can't handle the armadas that everyone has towards the endgame, but I still keep making new games because I love the immersive value. There's more to just a game grid with a galaxy color scheme, there's more to planets than their sizes. The game doesn't pull you into an immersive experience, you won't even notice the transition.  For example, on my first playthrough I had a mining station on an asteroid in a middle of nowhere system. As I researched more and more, that asteroid turned out to hold a bunch of strategic resources. Lucky me, right? Then my neighbors, peace loving tapeworms, colonized a nearby planet and suddenly I no longer owned that asteroid. By this time I had found another exo-planet with equal value, but I went to war over this asteroid. The game refused to let me name the war, but I always refer to it as the 'War of the Rock'. The War of the Rock took twenty years, and saw the tapeworms lose twelve admirals before sneaking a fleet by my lines and bombarding my home planet. My population enraged and my key fleet-building station compromised, I gave my last admiral the divine blessings and ordered him to punch right into the tapeworm home system and lay waste. The War of the Rock resulted in a single asteroid's mining rights return to its previous owners and a Democratic Utopia crumble under the weight of rampant genoicde carried out by my vengeaful populace.  This is one possibility of interactions with an empire you encounter on the playing field. Gameplay wise, I could have conceded for economic reasons but I didn't. It wasn't a game then, and I still had 22 more Empires to interact with while the crime of genoicde hung over my empire. That's 22 potential space epics for you as well. And Paradox is doing all it can to help you make even more, because YOU'RE the storyteller in this one.  9/10, needs ship coloring and war naming. Oh wait; 11/10, makes up for it in endless entertainment derived from just staring at a planet grow and thinking of the horse colonists working side by side with robots and tentacled neighbors.

I have been holding off on Reviewing Stellaris because I wanted a clear picture of what the game is!  After having put more then 100 Hours into Stellaris I have found that I still can't answer that question reliably.  So I think I am going to start off with Broad Questions:  Is the game fun? Yes Is the game good? Yes Would I recommend this game to others? Yes Is it worth its price tag? Yes  So with that part out of the way I want it to be clear that I very much like this game BUT:  Stellaris is having a hard time claiming to be a Grand Strategy game!  It lacks Casus Beli's The Game Pace is far too fast, it takes about as long as a Civ 5 game! There is a complete lack of content for any playstyle thats not map painting! Diplomacy is Abysmal And Bug's are Galore  Basically I get NO Grand Stategy feel too Stellaris when I play it! Infact it sometimes feels like it wants to be a Grand Strategy game but its not capable in its current form of grasping that role! The game basically feels Naked with only two victory conditions that both involve lots of Pew Pew.....  So then I try to compare it too 4X games of new and old and well that leaves me in a similiar confused condition. It just doesnt jive in my mind. At times I feel some Masters of Orion or Galactic Civ like gameplay but by and large its so confused on its identity that it doesn't feel '4X' either....  So one of my biggest issues that I am having at this point in time is simply trying to classify Stellaris in my mind. But whatever classification it finally evolves into its far from complete. That is the one thing that really rings true when I play the game currently (1.0.2 - 5/17/2016 Only 8 days since release) its not fnished. Infact it often times feels like I am in a building with no walls just the 2*4 Frame and a roof.... There is a ton of work to do yet, its pretty obvious!   (Understand I am a Hardcore Paradox Fan who expects a Certain Level of product from Paradox) The things I dislike the most:  Diplomacy:  -Very Lacking in options.  -The options you do have are again rarely if ever excepted by the AI unless you meet a very specific parameter. -The AI itself fails to use the few diplomatic options that are currently in the game correctly.  Victory Conditions: -An utter and complete lack of a victory type that doesnt involve Pew Pew??? You feel like you have more options playing as the Germans in Heart's of Iron then any Race in Stellaris....   Events: - Severly lacking, this is the part I am most disappointed with, as all the short comings above I could easily ignore if there seemed like there was a credible effort put in to really make the world rich with events.... I really think the lack of events is what most makes Stellaris not feel like it has an Identity in my mind. And then the events that are in the game are so MEH.... They almost feel like background flavor that has little relevance.   But with all that said,  Stellaris is a GEM its got a skeleton in place that has the potential to become a game thats better then Crusader Kings 2.... It has the potential to be one of the greatest of all time. Its addictive, its flashy, its a must buy! This game is everything it has been advertised to be. It is a fantastic space strategy simulation. The perfect mix of RPG elements into a strategy game brings out so many hidden gems to slobber over that I can hardly do them justice with a simple description.  As an avid Sci-Fi reader, what impresses me the most is how well read the Paradox Interactive team must be. The Sci-Fi tropes from all the classic novels, all the best of so many different worlds and minds are spread lightly across the top like salt on some perfectly fried french fries.  -Robots and a possible AI revolution.  -Uplift Species from mere planetbound life to sentience and the ability to travel beyond the stars. As your true companions or as your genetically engineered slaves.  -Find planets of pre-spaceflight aliens and observe from orbit or become more 'intrusive' in your scientific pursuit of studying alien culture. -Grow Clone Armies in vats to fight your wars for you. -Build a Slave Center and brainwash your alien slaves to fight as your invasion army. -Be a friend to all and create a United Federation of Species to share knowledge and explore. -Re-engineer your own species to adapt to new worlds, or terraform the worlds to suit your own needs. Why not do both? -Send you science ships to the far reaches of the galaxy and explore strange new worlds. -Build massive fleets of your own design and pit them against your rivals. Or simply use the auto-build feature.  There is so much to see and do I can't fathom the scale of it, and i've barely brushed the surface. It will take me several hundred hours of playtime to really say I know the game well.

If you're impatient, this is not the genre, development/publishing company, or review for you.   I thoroughly enjoy myself playing at its current state. Empire creation is flexible and fun. At the beginning, surveying with my science ships has an excellent exploratory feel to it. The research 'card shuffle' is a breath of fresh air from other tech trees. Battles can take place where I don't have to babysit so I can focus on other areas of my empire. The quest/anomaly chains are well written and keep things interesting.    Yes, there are things that need improvement, of which, you can find on the forums/reddit ad infinitum. Some are valid, some are unrealistic pipe dreams.  That doesn't stop me from enjoying stories I derive and the time spent figuring out the systems. The entertainment received more than justifies the $40.  I can't wait to see the direction they take the game. The devs are transparent and have a solid plan to address the issues.   RIP Mercedes Romero.
Yes, there are edges that need polish. There are systems that need fleshing out. There are shortcomings with the AI. Meanwhile, I plugged in a couple of mods and am very much enjoying this game.

Now, Stellaris is one of those games where you can just tell that the dev team cared a lot about their game and worked really hard to make it as great as they possibly could. As soon as you get into the game you realize just how large this games potential could be, from you being able to create your own species all the way down to it's ideals and beliefs, to being able to bring the entire galaxy under your control and all the other races in it. Unfortunately for all it's polish and care, the game has quite a few bugs, especially for one that has never been in early access, but the majority of them that I encountered were mostly minor (graphical glitches and UI problems). So I'm going to list all the good and the bad about the game and make my judgement from there.  Pros:  (+) Game's art style is astounding and obviously a lot of care went into every detail.  (+) Gameplay is solid and entertaining, even hours later.   (+) The amount of technologies, weapons, and designs means that even though there are very few ship designs, it still feels like you're fighting something new.  (+) Subtle references to other space related movies and games, like having a Xenomorph army from the Alien movies or one of the fungal races being like a virus taking over a host's body like in the Last of Us.   Cons:  (-) Quite a few bugs. Even though they were minor ones, they were in just the right place to make them more noticable (and more annoying). Things like the portrait of a planet's background showing up black, or a large green box covering the top 25% of the screen when you open a menu.  (-) The ships don't default to your flag's colors, and there is no ship painter. This can be disappointing when you're engaging a race that uses the same ships as you do, and that they look exactly like you do.  (-) Little room for expansion. This game suffers from what most other 4X games do, in that, it places your neighbors extremely close together. I understand that it's for action's sake but sometimes when you are surrounded by neighbors who hate you, there really isn't much you can do.  Overall, I have to give the game an 8/10. It's really fun and looks and sounds nice in places, but there are a few glaring issues that could and hopfully can be fixed. Maybe with a patch, maybe with future DLC, but fixed either way. I'd definitely recommend Stellaris to anyone who likes space games, 4X games, or the sort.

My likes: Scratches an itch for a space RTS/4X hybrid that I've wanted to play for a long time (good balance of base building, diplo, and offense), easiest to learn Paradox game to date in my experience, replayability, tons of character, a solid game to continue to add on to (Paradox tends to continually develop in fair depth after release).  Conclusion: Stellaris has some holes, and needs some additional support, but for the price the value is already there.

Stellaris sets a new standard for 4X interstellar gameplay. Those who have played other Paradox grand strategy games, namely CK2, will feel right at home in the interface. Those new to the game need to learn to rely on tooltips for detailed information, but it's a quick adjustment and the crisp and logical interface makes learning the game's systems a breeze. The soundtrack is amazing as well. Mod support is fantastic and there are already tons of mods on the marketplace. As with any relese, there are bugs to be found, but Paradox's customer support is the best I've seen from any game company. I encountered a bug causing a crash after 100 years and I submitted a bug report. Paradox patched the game and fixed the issue that same day. They are active on reddit and other online forums/networks and constantly communicating with the players. Some systems currently lack depth and espionage is absent, but as with any Paradox title, I fully expect to see tons of cheap DLC's released expanding all these systems as time goes on. That does not mean the game is not fully fleshed out right now. The species creation system allows you to replicate any sci-fi species you want, aside from some portraits not matching perfectly. The ship designer is perfectly balanced and allows for tons of customization without being a spaceship designing sim. The combat systems are excellently balanced. 'Deck of cards' tech tree is fun, interesting, and adds depth to the game rather than being a frustration as I had anticipated. This is the 4X space strategy game I've been waiting years for. Seriously, I can't put this one down, 64 hours in almost exactly one week. My only complaint, Paradox, is that this happened to be finals week.... WHY?!

I just learned about and bought this game yesterday. I've played it for around 6 hours so far. This is relatively similar to a concept I had for a space 4x game. It is refreshing to see the direction this game takes with alien civilizations, contact with them, the various special research projects, etc. It is also nice to see the sector concept get added even though it is done a bit differently than I would have done. Overall, the game is quite fun and addicting. They have successfully stopped colony spam and ship spam. They are finally no longer the de-facto tactic to winning a 4x strategy game, despite the fact that they have kept colonization and fleet building an important part of the overall strategy. I'm not entirely sold on the randomness of which technologies show up on the list for research. It certainly adds some flare to the research process, but I think it's a bit too random. I think it needs to weight the lower cost techs higher the further into the research tree you progress so that you always have at least one lower cost option available to research. I've had too many times where the only techs I can research are ones which take ages to complete while missing out on much needed weapons upgrades. I also find it refreshing that planetary improvements complete in a reasonable amount of time and that the whole game is not all about managing your colonies. I would like to see a notification come up each time a planet finishes growing a population, however. That would let me stop digging through my planets to find where I need to build a new structure. But, as I said, overall, it is a very good game.

I feel that, after 540+ hours of conquering the galaxy, I should probably write a review about Stellaris.  Firstly, a TL:DR. Stellaris is a wonderful strategy game that I feel I'll be playing for a long time yet with charming graphics and an excellent soundtrack too. It isn't without its flaws, but I'm confident they'll be improved on over time. Definitely a worthwhile buy.  Now, onwards!  Positives  Graphics and Sound: I don't generally care about graphics in my games. Content is much more important to me. But for Stellaris, I'll make an exception. The graphics are amazing, the soundrack is wonderful. The charming portraits and all the extra details the graphics bring to the game does it wonders, really helping to make the galaxy feel alive. From the little animations of the pops to the stunning laser weapons (I just love the tachyon lances), Stellaris has done such a great job with the aesthetics, I feel it worthy of comment.  Early Game: The early game is truly where Stellaris shines. It has, arguably, the best early game I've ever played in a strategy game. Thanks to the anomalies, pre-scripted systems, randomly generated stuff, space monsters, and a whole host of other things, it managed to create a sense of wonder found in few other places. I never tire of finding anomalies (even though I've basically seen them all), or stumbling across a pre-set system (which I won't spoil). And simply preventing communications with aother empire until I translate their language makes things slightly more unknown, slightly more tense.  Stories: To be clear, the game doesn't directly make stories, rather the events of any given game are perfecft for making unique, memorable stories that I can't help but tell everyone else about. It's a joy to be able to recount how I sacrificed everything to halt a signficant threat to the galaxy with the aid of my federation friends, or how my space foxes used cockroaches from an irradiated Earth to drive off the Human Remnant and prevent their conquest/purging of the galaxy. Though it can't quite compare to CK2, Stellaris still makes for some wonderful tales of galactic history.  Neutral Points  Sectors: This is a hugely debated issue, and one I don't actually feel strongly about. Sectors handle every system beyond the core worlds (default, you can have five core systems. This increases with tech, and can be modded). Yeah, sure, the sector AI is a bit... incapable. But I always see sectors as the undesirable side-effect of building a galactic empire; I can't physically run everything. Sure, I could micromanage every colony, but I don't especially want to. And I can mod it if I need to. Sectors can be a pain, but don't detract enough to spoil the overall game noticeably (for me at least).  War: An odd one perhaps, for a war game. I really enjoy war, on the whole. The doomstack battles make last stands seem so satisfying, and since it's all dictated by Lanchester's Square Law, I appreciate how this is the inevitable outcome in space. The problem is that, although the big battles are impressive, it means that in any given war there's really only one big decisive battle. And then it's just a case of conquering planets and swatting the odd raider. Again, this doesn't detract enough to spoil the game, but means I can't really say war is excellent (yet).  Negatives  Diplomacy: Don't get me wrong, I don't hugely mind the diplomacy. There's a reason I build federations. But it's a bit lackluster, and a little problematic at times. I usually only trade resources as bribes. Federations make the AIs a bit... enthusiatic... about who they want to be friends with. Certain events completely mess up the diplomacy. And it's way too easy to ignore the diplomacy and just rampage across the galaxy. All in all, diplomacy just ends up disappointing me.  This is a non-exhaustive list, I can go on forever. But I hope it may be of help for potential buyers in some, small way.

TL;DR: Read the Conclusion at the bottom of this review!  2265 A.D. - 3 Collective (meaning Slavers) alien races declare war onme. They have a combined strength of 15K-20K. Me, playing as the human United Nations, had overstretched. Too many planets, and a navy with only 2K strength to fend off 3 enemies with 10 times my military size. There was no way I could win, so I cede. I negotiate a peace treaty with 2 of the alien races and give them 2 of my planets  They then proceeded to enslave every human on the 2 planets I gave them. I had abandoned my own people to slavery on the promise of colonial riches. I actually felt bad for abandoning them :'(  But I also went into a fit of rage. I was still fighting 1 alien enslaving empire. Despite still being outnumbered, I fought a war of attrition, getting them to attack my space stations to decrease their strength, despite losing some of my space stations. My economy went into overdrive, every planet was churning out ships and I was running a government budget deficit.  2281 A.D. - After 16 years of war, I defeated the alien bug race with whom I had was still fighting against. I had smashed their military and economic strength and my allies, who initially didn't send fleets in, eventually sent them over and helped me defeat my enemy.  But the other 2 empires still had control over my 2 planets that I ceded to them. Worse yet, the humans they enslaved there were running out - THEY WERE FORBIDDEN FROM BREEDING :'(  There was still much work to be done.  2291 A.D. - After the 10 year ceasefire was over, I went to war again with the alien race I had smashed earlier. I won in 3 years, although I failed to successfully capture their capital planet, their homeworld, I still managed to take out the rest of their planets and establish a Vassal State which eventually integrated into my empire.  Initially, I purged some of the aliens living in the vassal state that I made once they integrated, but my people didn't like that since they were very individualistic and as such, I went back on my purge policy. Purging is a combination of ethnic/species cleansing and genocide.  But the 2 other empires still had my 2 planets where there were still a few humans left.  2309 A.D. - A few years before, the 2 empires that still had the 2 planets with humans enslaved in them had gone to war against another, powerful empire. This was good news, all I had to do was wait. Eventually their military would wind down, they would become weak, and then I could strike, reclaim the 2 lost planets with whatever humans were still left there after over 5 decades of slavery :(  in 2309, the time came. I negotiated help from a different empire that I had good relations with. My plan was, I can't go after both the empires on my own, but if I can keep one empire distracted by fighting a war with my ally, I can focus on the other one.  2325 A.D. - The plan worked. After another 15 year war, humans were once again united everywhere. It had been almost 3/4ths of a century since those planets were lost in a peace settlement which saw them abandoned, so I decided to give them their own independent state, but I also sent them a guaranteed monthly economic aid of minerals and energy credits to help them themselves back up on their feet. It comprised almost 25% of monthly government profit. Within 2 weeks they asked to become a vassal so they could be protected properly. Soon they will be re-integrated back with the rest of humanity.  So what happens next? I don't know, but I now enjoy having the most powerful military in my region of the galaxy, and a healthy economy capable of growing my military into twice or even 3 times the size it currently is.   CONCLUSION: This game gives you amazing stories. Let your imagination go wild and run free, it's the best way to enjoy this magnificent work of artistry that Paradox has produced =)  I give it a solid 8.6/10.

Stellaris is not perfect, but still a fun game with lasting appeal. Creating your very own civilization with custom traits and government style allows the player to rule the galaxy in his/her style. The art style and music are truly wonderful. The addition of Leviathan DLC provides further enjoyment in mid/late game. The combat is mediocre, but the game forces the player to set goals and objectives for wars prior to the declaration. This mechanism prohibits boring unending wars from occurring, which frequently results in later stages of many other grand strategy games. Where the game is lacking, however, is diplomacy. Diplomatic options are available, but I seldom felt I could negotiate with or manipulate A.I. players.  Despite its flaws, I thoroughly enjoyed Stellaris, and will continue to do so for a long time. I’ve also felt that the developers are actively listening to the community feedback and improving the game bit by bit. If you enjoy games like Civilization, Anno, or the campaign portion of Total War, I recommend Stellaris.

I like Stellaris, but it has flaws. These will likely be fixed or improved by DLC. This is my summary as of 1.3.2    Pro:  Stellaris is the only game I have seen that simulates the old sci-fi trope of colonies ideologically diverging from their home planet. Build multi species empire and deal with diverse pops through assimilation, migration, slavery or purging.  Emergent storytelling and lots of different event chains.  Cons:  Not enough weapons for my taste. It currently has only three classes of weapons (missiles, ballistics and energy) and missiles are not competitive.  Not enough freedom in ship design and not enough classes of ships. There are currently only four classes of ship. These are not well balanced right now either.  Star bases are very underpowered mid to late game. Early game, bases and star docks will stop early rushes, as it should be. Once you overcome that hurdle, bases become more or less worthless outside of niche uses. They fail to scale in power with fleets.  Combat is similar to EU4, and I think that is a bit of a shame.  End game threats need a rebalance. Many are too weak and the Awakened Empires are too strong.  Lots of micromanagement with exploration.  A terrible sector system that only allows you to control 5 planets at a time. The rest must be given to the AI to run.

This is not a perfect game, with some AI aspects still needing work, and if you are new to Paradox games, the resource system might seem peculiar, but once you understand the mechanics, and see that the scope of the game is massive, and that the amount of replayability is next to infinite, and that 99% of what the game does it does well, this is a title that just cannot be missed!

There is a lot I can say for this game. It has given me tons. I've played at least a dozen playthroughs on my own. I even started play-by-consensus version of it on Reddit, where the subscribers are citizens in the empire, form parties, run for election, and generate legislation. I use that to inform my playthrough (if interested PM me).  There is tons more improvement needed for the game. But that is what I like about Paradox. There games will get tons of free patches with major overhauls and great DLC. I never felt Crusader Kings was complete until the Old Gods came out.  That being said, Stellaris has some amazing potential. You can really feel the kind of diversity in playthroughs even at this early stage, just by choosing what FTL system you will use. I (like most) started with Warp, but Hyperdrive and Jumpgates are both fun...and most importantly. Play very differently.  With Warp, your ships are pretty much autonomous and free functioning, but their warp systems draw heavily on power and increase the cost for production.  Hyperdrive ships still require a good bit of power for their systems, I think the cost is reduced. What is most important is that they have some of the quickest cooldowns after arriving in a system. That being said you are dependent upon a pre-existing hyperspace network to get anywhere.  Wormhole requires the least amount of power and least cost to the ships. The ships have a large spinup time (as the ships prepare to take off). However, you are very dependent on wormhole stations, and essentially create your own logistics/transport network. If you have 6 fleets moving through a system and only one wormhole station, you can expect a long wait for all of them. If you have 2 stations, you half that time, and so forth. Wormholes allow you to literally jump over enemy space into pockets of unclaimed terra nullius. However, for all these benefits there are major drawbacks. A smart enemy can target your logistics network and strand your fleets. Imagine sending a big fleet to confront an enemy medium sized fleet, while you are doing this, a smaller lightning raid takes out your wormhole stations and harrasses constructors at the closest system. All of a sudden your fleet is stuck.  This kind of variety is already ingrained into the gameplay, and I expect to see more of it. Just as Merchant Republics changed things for CKII, I imagine we will be seeing new ways the game can/will be played. There are some problems, but those will get handled in due time.
